                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="50" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The laboratory course in organic chemistry will introduce basic techniques of preparative organic chemistry. Simple organic reactions will be conducted, including several single-step and multi-step syntheses. Purification procedures, including recrystallization, distillation, sublimation, and chromatography will be introduced. Methods of sample identification will include melting point, infrared spectroscopy, UV spectrophotometry, and NMR spectroscopy. Participants must have taken Chemical Safety Instruction to attend (announced separately).<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The 1st year labs will take place on Thursdays and Fridays, 14:15-18:30.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This second-year course deals with statistical mechanics and thermodynamics as well as with basic quantum mechanics and molecular structure. In statistical mechanics, the ensemble is introduced and the laws of thermodynamics are derived from the partition function.<br />Distributions for different ensembles are derived. Illustrative applications are chosen e.g.<br />from liquid theory. The molecular quantum mechanics part introduces the necessary subset of quantum mechanics and the main results for vibrators, rotators and electronic systems. Chemical bonds are duscussed in terms of simple molecular-orbital theory. With the results from quantum mechanics, molecular spectroscopies (e.g. infrared, Raman, microwave and photoelectron) are discussed.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course deals with advanced inorganic and coordination chemistry. It is intended for majors in Chemistry, Biochemical Engineering, Biochemistry and Cell Biology. Topics: d-metal Complexes (structures and symmetries, bonding and electronic structure, reactions of complexes), The Electronic Spectra of Complexes (electronic spectra of atoms, electronic spectra of complexes, bonding and spectra of M-M bonded compounds), Catalysis (general principles, homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous catalysis), Reaction Mechanisms of d-metal Complexes (ligand substitution reactions in square-planar and octahedral complexes, redox reactions, photochemical reactions).<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        In Advanced Laboratory Course Physical Chemistry, participants gain hands-on experience in three important fields of Physical Chemistry: thermodynamics, kinetics, and electrochemistry. <br />The experiments selected exemplify topics discussed in Physical Chemistry lecture (400211) taught as a part of the Advanced Chemistry lectures. Participants will investigate fundamental aspects and modern developments of Physical Chemistry to improve their skills in quantitative analysis of experimental data. An important part is the recognition of error sources and assessment of the quality of the result. <br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course will deal with the area of physical-organic chemistry and requires the fundamental knowledge from the preceding organic and physical chemistry courses, in particular Advanced Chemistry AI and BI. The course will cover the following areas: Conformational analysis and molecular mechanics, applications of molecular orbital theory and valence bon, reactive intermediates, spectroscopic methods of studying chemical reactions and reaction mechanisms, and applications to various reaction types. Two special chapters will be dedicated to mechanistic photochemistry and supramolecular chemistry.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The lab/research project course can be performed in any chemistry research area at Jacobs University with the chemistry faculty and research instructors as potential supervisors. This includes research in the following areas offered at Jacobs University: organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, physical and physical-organic chemistry, computational chemistry and biochemistry, analytical chemistry, environmental chemistry, nanoscience, supramolecular chemistry, biomolecular chemistry. This course is carried out by working in a chemistry research group at Jacobs University with work times being individually scheduled. It is the responsibility of the student to find a supervisor for his/her research project. Typically, the student fulfills the requirements by working for one full semester in the same research group. Eligible courses are approved by the instructor of record.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The chemistry seminar series will include presentations by guest speakers, Jacobs University chemistry faculty, Jacobs University graduate and undergraduate students on research topics or literature review. Scheduling of the seminar slots is flexible, with typically one weekly session. Participating students and faculty will be informed through an e-mail list about upcoming seminars. This seminar counts 3 credits for graduate students and 1.5 credits for undergraduate students in relation to the student work load required. The course will deal<br />with the area of physical-organic chemistry and requires the fundamental knowledge from the<br />preceding organic and physical chemistry courses, in particular Advanced Chemistry AI and BI.<br />The course will cover the following areas: Conformational analysis and molecular mechanics, applications of molecular orbital theory and valence bon, reactive intermediates, spectroscopic methods of studying chemical reactions and reaction mechanisms, and applications to various reaction types. Two special chapters will be dedicated to mechanistic photochemistry and supramolecular chemistry.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (30%)<br />Home Work (30%)<br />Exam 1 (20%)<br />Exam 2 (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will provide students with the opportunity to learn how to apply the fundamentals of strength of materials as related to concepts of stress, strain, bending, torsion, stability, and deflection of deformable bodies to applications concerning bars, shafts, beams, columns, and pressure vessels.  Course materials focus on the fundamentals of applying equilibrium, compatibility of deformations, and force-deformation relationships in solving problems. Students are required to demonstrate proficiency in calculating stresses and strains in bars and beams subjected to axial forces and torsional/bending moments, and also combinations of these loadings; analyzing external and internal forces and moments; calculating deflections of beams; calculating angles of twist of shafts; determining reactions for indeterminate bars, shafts, and beams, and design of bars, shafts, and beams.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  0" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;

                                                                        Gen CS II&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Gen CS II" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course continues the introduction of the fundamental concepts and techniques of Computer Science. Building on Boolean Algebra, it<br /> introduces Propositional Logic as a model for general logical systems (syntax, semantics, calculi).  Based on elementary graph theory, combinatory circuits are introduced as basic logic computational devices. Interpreting sequences of Boolean values as representations of numbers (in positional number systems, twos-complement system), Boolean circuits are extended to numerical computational machines (presenting adders, subtracters, multipliers) and extended to basic ALUs. The course introduces very elementary computer architectures and assembly language concrete computational devices, and compares them to Turing machines to fathom the reach of computability.<br /><br />In a final part of the course, two topics of general Computer Science are covered in depth, for instance ``search algorithms'' and ``programming as search'' to complement the rather horizontal (i.e. methods-oriented) organization of the course with vertically (i.e. goal-oriented) organized topics.<br /><br />Topics<br />Propositional logic, calculi, soundness, completeness, automated theorem proving, combinatory circuits, assembler turing machines, search, logic programming.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Grade (0%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The first part of this course introduces core components<br />(processors, memory systems, busses) and architectures of modern computing systems.  The second part of this course provides an introduction to the concepts underlying operating systems. Students will develop an understanding how operating systems realize a virtual machine that can be used to execute multiple concurrent application programs and how concurrency problems can be solved.<br /><br />Topics:<br />Computer architectures, processors, instruction sets, memory systems, system busses, parallel processing, operating system, architectures, system calls and interrupts, concurrent processes and threads, scheduling, synchronization, deadlocks, virtual memory,<br />file systems, inter-process communication, socket programming interface.<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is an introduction to software engineering and object-oriented software design. At the core of the lecture is the notion of software quality and the methods to achieve and maintain it in environments of "multi-person construction of multi-version software" [Parnas 1987].<br /><br />Based on their pre-existing knowledge of an object-oriented programming language, students are familiarized with software architectures, design patterns and frameworks, software components and middleware, UML-based modelling, and validation by testing. Further, the course addresses the more organisational topics of project management and version control. Practical work underpins this by looking at suitable tools.<br /><br />The course is recommended to all students on whose software skills people will depend one day.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Course topics: Embedded hardware and networking, mobile energy supply, sensors, motors, mechanics, mechatronics,manipulation, locomotion, control and modeling, cooperation of multiple systems. <br />Role of course within curriculum: Robotics is a field that spans the entire range from low-level mechatronics and signal processing to high-level cooperation protocols of intelligent agents, and thus touches large portions of both CS and EE. Correspondingly, the course aims at an integrative, practically oriented education that enables students to practically combine methods he/she has encountered in various more specialized courses before. An active robotics lab and participation in international robot contests give additional substance and motivation to this course.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Course topics: clock synchronization, logical and vector clocks, reliable, causal and atomic multicasts, virtual synchrony, election algorithms, voting algorithms, consistent snapshots, security. <br />Role of the course in the curriculum: This course focusses on distributed algorithms that are the foundation for complex and fault-tolerant distributed systems. The material covered has been selected to provide a solid overview over the key algorithms and todevelop an understanding of the issues that influence solutions for a certain problem in a distributed system.  This course is recommended for EECS students with a strong interest in communication networks.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Grading and exams: There will be four miniquizzes (written in class, 20 minutes), the best three of which will each  account to 20% of the final grade (worst will be dropped from calculating the grade), and one final exam, counting 30%. All quizzes are open book. Each quiz or exam yields a maximum of 100 points. The total semester points Pts_total are computed as the weighted semester point average (each quiz points are weighted by 0.15, the final by 0.3, the homeworks by 0.1), and from Pts_total the final grade is computed by the standard Jacobs formula which essentially (up to some rounding subtleties) assigns a 1.0 grade to points 96100, a 1.33 grade to points 9195, etc. in steps of 5 points until a grade of 5.00 is hit with 40 points or less. Numerical rounding will follow from the Excel formula used in the process, which was given to faculty by the registrar.<br /><br />Miniquiz makeup rules: if a miniquiz is missed without excuse, it will be graded with 0 points. An oral makeup will be offered for medically excused miniquizzes according to the Jacobs rules (especially, the medical excuse must be announced to me on the day of the miniquiz). Non-medical excuses can be accepted and miniquiz makeups be arranged on a case-by-case basis.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This lecture presents one half of the core material of theoretical computer science (the other half is covered in the lecture ``Formal Languages and Logic''). The question: ``What problems can a computer possibly solve?'', is fully answered (by characterizing those solvable problems, equivalently, through Turing machines, random access machines, recursive functions and lambda calculus). A full answer to the related question, ``how much computational resources are needed for solving a given problem'' is not known today. However, the basic outlines of today's theory of computational<br />  complexity will be presented up to the most famous open problem in computer science, namely the famous ``P = NP'' question: if a computer can guess the answer to a problem (and only needs to check its correctness), does that really help to speed up computation?<br /><br />Topics:<br />Computable functions and complexity, lambda calculus, functional programming.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course homepage is http://minds.jacobs-university.de/teaching/CCSpring2012. It will become accessible shortly before the semester starts. I use that course page for all documentation (schedule, detailed grading info, references, lecture notes...) and for the day-to-day communication (exercise sheets in particular). I will NOT use the Campus Web page! <br /><br />A self-contained, complete set of online lecture notes will be provided. Additional background reading for the ones who want to probe deeper will be indicated on the course homepage.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="40" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This lab unit is a continuation of the first semester lab Programming in Python I. It covers advanced topics of Python programming such as object oriented programming, advanced data structures, file handling, debugging techniques and problem solving using frameworks.<br />This lab is a service lab aimed at students who do not need to learn how to program in C in a mandatory lab. Students studying ECE, EECS, CS and ACM need to take NatSciLab CS II instead.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Lab attendance is mandatory.                                                                         <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        GenGeo&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="GenGeo" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Midterm Exam (50%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is a continuation of the first-semester lecture General Earth and Space Sciences. The concepts are developed further and in a more quantitative way. The geology unit starts with a brief geological history of the Earth, provides an introduction to crystallography, addresses the rock cycle and provides an introduction to hydrogeology to reflect the increasing importance of fresh water resources. The geology part finishes with an outline of different sedimentological processes and features. Topics of the oceanography unit include the ocean as a biogeochemical system and the marine carbon cycle including the marine carbonate system. Also the role of the ocean as a resource of minerals, the use and misuse of the ocean, and environmental issues will be presented.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Astrophysics unit (50%)<br />Space physics unit (50%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In astrophysics, heliophysics, and space exploration, fundamental concepts are developed further and in a more quantitative way. <br />The astrophysics unit covers a range of topics including the nature, the birth, and the evolution of stars, our galaxy as well as galaxies in general, supermassive black holes and active galactic nuclei, and concludes with a short discussion of cosmological evolution starting from the Big Bang until now. The space physics unit  comprises topics from the heliophysics and space exploration. Heliophysics deals with the Sun and the heliosphere, solar activity and space weather, geomagnetic storms and auroral lights, as well as energetic particles in the near-Earth space environment. The space exploration unit addresses challenges and technical aspects of space flight as well as ongoing and future space missions.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="5" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="27" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Introduction to the fundamentals of field geology and field oceanography. <br />The students have to participate in a weekend field trip that includes an introductory seminar (details will be announced by the instructor of record), the field trip itself, and follow-up work such as data analysis, and the preparation of a report that is graded.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The excursion is taking place from 25.04.-28.04.2012 in Helgoland.<br /><br />Since there are only 27 places available for this excursion, preference will be given to, in order:<br />1. ESS and IES majors<br />2. third year students, who meet the pre-requisites <br />3. third year students, who do not meet the pre-requisites.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will introduce you to Geographic Information System (GIS) principles and provide you with the necessary skills and expertise needed to analyse Earth and Space Science data. A GIS allows us to combine data visually and computationally for spatial correlation, analysis, modelling and calculation. In this context, GIS has become the universal tool to integrate, analyse, manage and visualize large volumes of spatial data from multiple sources at a variety of scales. These concepts will be demonstrated and hands-on training provided using state-of-the-art software. Examples of applications to various fields such as geo- and bio-sciences, data management, habitat mapping, risk assessment and geo-marketing will be discussed and the role of the Internet in data mining and Web GIS will also be demonstrated.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        During the excursion field techniques in the geosciences will be practised and "textbook geology" will be compared to "real world geology". During a four day excursion to the Eifal area of Western Germany, which is famous for its mantle xenoliths, its Tertiary and Quaternary volcanism, and its sedimentology and water chemistry. Fieldwork during the day will be complemented by evening seminars.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Excursions to practice and train field techniques in the geosciences. Part II is an oceanographic and marine geoscience excursion to Helgoland will take place on FS Heincke. The course provides students an excellent opportunity to gain some practical hands- on experience. They will be able to put to test various theories they have learned during their lectures over the past two years. It will also support and foster team work as they will have to process and interpret the acquired data as a group and write a cruise report. For cruise preparation and providing theoretical background an evening seminar prior to the cruise is mandatory.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The excursion will take place from 10.-14.04.2012<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This class extends and builds on the first year courses on physical oceanography and marine sciences in general. The course focuses on the large-scale circulation of the oceans and includes temperature-salinity analysis, water mass identification, water, salt, and heat budgets. The distribution of chemical tracers, advection and diffusion will be discussed.<br />The sources, reactions, and fates of organic molecules in the marine environment along with<br />the stable isotope geochemistry of marine organic substances will be presented. In addition,<br />various aspects of marine exploration and science will be touched upon. Those interested in<br />the oceanography specialization must attend this course.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Midterm Exam (60%)<br />Presentation (40%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The mid-term exam (scheduled for March) will cover the content of the module "Human interactions with the environment".<br />The presentation (scheduled for May) will cover the module "Natural changes of the environment".<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will cover the development of the atmosphere and the hydrosphere throughout Earth's history from the beginning of the geological record to modern times and will focus on geological, cosmogenic and anthropogenic changes. Several major events in the evolution of the Earth will be discussed, such as the evolution of an oxic atmosphere and ocean, onset of early life, snowball Earth, mass-extinctions in Earth history, and modern glaciation cycles. In the second part of the course, human interactions with natural systems will be discussed. Besides climate change and global<br />warming (natural vs. anthropogenic causes), the focus will be placed upon anthropogenic contamination of the environment and global consequences for the atmosphere and hydrosphere. The principles of contaminant transports and uptake by organisms will be introduced. Heavy metal cycling in terrestrial and marine environments, behavior and transport of organic pollutants (examples: TBT, PCBs, DDT, etc.), and radioactive compounds in the<br />ocean will be some of the discussed topics. The course shall include a one-day excursion with sampling of soil and water for environmental analysis.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Space Plasma Phys&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Space Plasma Phys" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Home Work (25%)<br />Midterm Exam (25%)<br />Midterm Exam 2 (25%)<br />Quizz(es) (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The Earth¿s environment in space is controlled by the interaction of the magnetised solar wind plasma with the geomagnetic field generated in the Earth¿s core. A geomagnetic cavity is formed in the interplanetary medium (namely, the magnetosphere) where a rich variety of dynamic phenomena can be observed. The dynamics of the magnetosphere gives rise to beautiful auroral displays but is also associated with failures of communication satellites. Furthermore, near-Earth space is a huge natural plasma laboratory accessible by spacecraft which helps to develop a consistent picture of fundamental plasma physical processes.<br />This course addresses both space plasma physics theory and observations. Spacecraft measurements and ground-based observations are presented to introduce prominent plasma phenomena in near-Earth space. The theoretical models discussed in class include the single-particle picture, single-fluid and multi-fluid magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), and plasma kinetic theory.<br />Emphasis will be on the plasma fluid concept that allows to study flows, waves, and discontinuities in the magnetosphere and in the solar wind.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course provides a forum for the presentation of talks on the complete range of topics encountered in the Earth and Space Sciences. It serves as an integrated platform for interdisciplinary discussion and exchange of information on ongoing research within the Earth and Space Sciences community at Jacobs University Bremen. Moreover, it promotes the development and improvement of oral presentation skills. <br />Participation in this seminar is mandatory for third-year students of Earth and Space Sciences.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Bachelor`s Thesis&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Majors in Geosciences and Astrophysics are supposed to work on small research projects called Guided Research Projects (GRPs) in their third year of study at IUB. This work is formally organized in the framework of Guided Research Courses (GRCs). A GRP may focus on experimental work, a field campaign, data analysis, computer simultations, theory, modelling, or a literature review. In order to be as effective as possible within the very limited amount of time, we stronlgy recommend to select one topic for both, the Fall and the Spring semester GRC. <br />The Fall semester GRC may involve a literature review in order to prepare for a project in Spring when a lab, field, data analysis, modelling, or theory project should be carried out. Students who are interested in taking a GRC in Geosciences and Astrophysics are invited to contact the instructors of record for more information on potential project topics. Each GRC must be concluded with a written report which will be graded.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Home Work (35%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (15%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The goal of this course is to provide understanding of ocean processes and their role in climate. Fundamental concepts and their mathematical description will be introduced. The course will derive the basic equations governing the oceanic circulation and the transport of mass and tracers in the ocean. Useful approximations to these equations and their range and applications will be discussed. Starting from problems like the variability of oceanic meridional heat transport and sea level change, the course will introduce important elements of the oceanic general circulation. Topics include adjustment processes through waves, Ekman boundary layers, wind-driven and thermohaline circulation.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        GenIES II&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="GenIES II" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Midterm Exam 1 (Environmental Geoscience) (34%)<br />Final Exam (Biology and Ecology) (33%)<br />Midterm Exam 2 (Energy Policy and Management) (33%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Biology module:<br />Biology is around us; we ourselves are components of "biology". To appreciate our position in Nature, we need to know something about life itself, about different life forms, and the way living organisms interact with each other and with environmental features. The lectures are designed to provide the students with a taste of "Biodiversity" and the concept of "Ecosystems". Towards that end some specific habitats may be explained in some detail: the open sea, the cave habitat, and "the polar realm".<br />Ecology module:<br />This module is an introduction to ecological thought and principles and is concerned with the main aspects influencing the distribution and abundance of organisms. We will examine the main physical factors of the environment that influence organisms and the way in which organisms are adapted to those factors. The major types of ecosystems, the biomes, will be briefly surveyed. The module covers topics in the areas of individual organisms, population, community, and ecosystem ecology. The dynamics of energy flow and chemical cycling in ecosystems is also treated and some of the consequences of human intrusions into these processes are considered.<br />Environmental Geoscience module:<br />It will be demonstrated how physical, chemical and biological processes interact in the geological environment and drive the functions of the ecosystem. Anthropogenic changes in the ecosystem at local and global scales will be discussed, with emphasis on the degradation of the atmosphere, soil, water and geological and biological resources caused by human activity. Strategies are proposed for reversing environmental degradation and maintaining a healthful and sustainable earth.<br />Environmental policy and management part II: <br />This part will follow up the first series in GES I but will step into more detail and more analysis of problems and policies. It will introduce two legs of environmental studies. First, how to deal with scarce resources in a sustainable way? What is sustainable in the first place? Second, how to deal with "external effects" (i.e. actions of economic agents that do affect others, but that are no priced)? Thirdly, we will illustrate in some depth these two pillars with specific current policies, like Emission Trading Scheme or renewable energy policies.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;
</tr><!-- KG START --><!-- KG END --></table>";s:12:"appointments";a:27:{i:0;a:4:{s:4:"date";s:17:"Wed, 1.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Active Participation (25%)<br />Presentation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br /><br />This course will cover the application of theoretical and empirical economics to the analysis of environmental and resource management issues. Specific topics will include global climate change, the relation between international trade and the environment, energy use, and the extraction of exhaustible and non-exhaustible resources. Cross-cutting these topics will be an emphasis on how economic analysis can contribute to contemporary policy debates.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Global Economics and Management (GEM), and Integrated Environmental Studies (IES)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br />- IES students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br />I WILL BE OBLIGED TO  GO ON A RESEARCH TRIP DURING THE TERM (MOST LIKELY TWO APPOINTMENTS). THOSE SESSIONS WILL TAKE PLACE THE 5TH OF MAY.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="35" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Essay (25%)<br />Presentation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course aims to characterize the "transition" to a sustainable and low-carbon energy world. The course will explain in detail the policy topics on renewable (or otherwise low-carbon) energy sources and sustainable energy use (aka energy efficiency) and other policies to achieve lowcarbon energy supply. (eg. CO2 emission trading). The course will rely on theories from economics, management, political science, sociology and psychology where applicable to explain and thereby prepare students to critically assess sustainable energy policy.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is mandatory for students choosing the "Energy Policy and Technology" specialization in the BSc program Integrated Environmental studies. <br /><br />- IES students wishing to take the "Energy Policy and Technology" specialization should register for this course in Spring 2 (semester 4). <br /><br />Students in the above mentioned cohort will be given priority at registration.  If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The IES seminar series provides a forum for the presentation of talks on the complete range of topics encountered in the program Integrated Environmental Studies. It serves as an integrated platform for interdisciplinary discussion and exchange of information on ongoing research within the community at Jacobs University Bremen related to the program. Apart from contributions by faculty and students from Jacobs University, external guest speakers will be invited. Moreover, the seminar promotes the development and improvement of oral presentations and discussion skills. Participation in the IES Seminar I and II is mandatory for second-year students of IES. The topics of the presentations will be defined in one of the first seminar sessions.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        ERDE field trip&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="ERDE field trip" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Active Participation (50%)<br />Report (50%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The excursion to East Frisia (Northern Germany) is comprised of several days with visits to sites such as an East Frisian Island , the UNESCO world heritage region Wadden Sea, the marsh polder land, the moraine "Geest" and/or the peat bogs. During the excursion to the various macrochores, the differences in the geology, pedology and ecology will be studied to understand the historic and present development of this dynamic landscape and the consequences of the climate change for these unique ecosystems and the society. Additionally the opportunities as well as consequences of development in renewable energy and the effects of the political decisions on the land use and landscape will be explored while visiting a windpark, biofuel plantations and a biogas plant.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Dr. Manfred Hinz</span>&#13;

                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        SustainDev&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="SustainDev" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Essay (60%)<br />Final Exam (40%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Assessment: Essay: 60%; final examination: 40%<br /><br />Essays: Essays are to be presented orally and in writing. The oral presentation should not last longer than 20  30 minutes. The written version of the presentation must be footnoted, properly referenced and about 10 to 15 single-spaced pages in length. It will be the task of each participant to search for the materials relevant to their essays.<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course Sustainable development: Political concept and legal implementation addresses a topic of prominence on international and national agenda as well as on agenda of non-state actors. Sustainable development, defined as the necessity of (m)eeting the needs of the present generation without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their needs (Brundtland Report:8), .has become a societal and political key concept since the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, now 20 years ago.<br />What does sustainable development mean? What are the normative implications of sustainable development, if any? What has been achieved in the last 20 years? To what extent has the famous Agenda 21 been translated into working programmes and legal measures? What is the way forward after the Durban conference of 2012 on the Kyoto Protocol? What is the way forward in securing biodiversity as part of the heritage of humankind?<br />Apart from an introduction to the overall topic of the course and a conclusion with remarks on the way forward, the course will be divided into three CHAPTERS:<br />CHAPTER I will look at the theoretical background behind sustainable development as a socio-political concept; CHAPTER II will be devoted to international attempts to translate the need for sustainable development into international soft law and law; CHAPTER III will focus on national and sub-national practices of implementing measures in favour of sustainable development.<br />Chapter I<br />The first part of chapter 1 of the course explores the philosophical dimension of the concept of sustainable development reaching out to the discourse going back to the groundbreaking philosophical focus on the imperative of responsibility (Prinzip Verantwortung) suggested by Hans Jonas, a suggestion that has influenced the debate since its promotion in 1979. <br />The second part will complement the philosophical approach with an anthropological perspective. This will be in line with what the Brundtland Report submited (12): Tribal and indigenous peoples will need special attention as the forces of economic development disrupt their traditional life-styles  life-styles that can offer modern societies many lessons in the management of resources in complex forest, mountain and dryland ecosystems. Emphasis will be led on the tribal / indigenous holistic view that keeps nature and culture interwoven and understands land to include the environment of the area which the people concerned traditionally occupy. (Agenda 21:paragraph 26.1)<br />The third part will extend the previous part by exploring the debate on worldviews and ecology.<br /><br />Chapter II<br />The first part of chapter II will explore the international debate initiated before and by the Brundtland Report, the results of the Rio Earth Summit of 1992, and its international evaluation since 1992. <br />The Rio Agenda 21 will be dealt with in the second part of the section.<br />Special attention will be given to the Kyoto Protocol and the Convention on Biological Diversity in the third part of chapter II.<br />In the fourth part of chapter II, the very particular problem of sustainable development in the law of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) will be evaluated.<br /><br />Chapter III<br />The first part of chapter III takes note of selected national achievements in translating the need for sustainable development into reality.<br />In the second part and third part of chapter III, special attention will be given to efforts and achievements of non-state actors: <br />in part two to so-called traditional communities using their own customary norms and practices to strengthen the sustainable use and management of natural resources, <br />in part three to communities (e.g. towns) which, in pursuance of the expectations of the Agenda 21, have embarked on projects to strengthen sustainable development. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Course starts 09.02.12!<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Hilke Brockmann</span>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        GlobalDemography&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="321524154940382" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Since people count demographers count people. Findings in demography are of interest to politicians, business people, public and to a wide range of sciences. Population questions occupy a central position in the research of economists, sociologists, geographers, historians, environmental scientists, and biologists. In this introductory lecture students will learn how global patterns of mortality, fertality and migration have altered and will change population development worldwide. The course focuses on crucial demographic contents and on formal techniques to make use and sense of demographic data. <br />We start out with a "thick" description of historical and global trends and contemporary demographic patterns. Then we get to know and to use measures and methods of demography like rates, population growth, age standardization, decomposition methods, mortality, fertality, and migration analysis. An introduction into standard life table techniques with aggregate and micro data will follow. We end with some population projections and their consequences for future societies.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="39" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Essay 1 (25%, Mandatory)<br />Essay 2 (25%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Group Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Quizzes (10%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course introduces the student to the theory and practice of public management and public policy analysis. On the one hand, the course will provide the student with an overview of what public management is today, how it has changed in the past 30 or so years and where it is going. Not only will the course expose students to contemporary thinking in public management, by looking at the way public managers over the world deal with today's policy challanges, the course will also allow students to apply this knowledge to real cases. On the other hand, the course exposes students to the conceptual and methodological tool-box of contemporary policy analysis and, by drawing on real-life examples from a variety of policy domains, shows students how academic and professional policy analysts bring this tool-box to bear on issues of public management and public policy. Additionally, the course will show how different socio-cultural, political or disciplinary frames of references shape policy analysis and how policy analysts can use these frames to sharpen their understanding of the way public institutions are managed.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH) and for BSc program Integrated Environmental Studies (IES) - "Energy Policy and Technology Specialization" <br />- IPH students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IES students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4). <br /><br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course will deepen selected fields of electrical engineering which were introduced in the course electrical engineering I (300101). These will include: Introduction to circuit analysis techniques, Signal processing and Communication Systems. In addition, there will be brief introductions to  control systems and energy systems. While providing some of the theoretical groundwork for the second year courses in electrical engineering, the practical aspects of the subjects will be kept in focus, too. The course should be accompanied by the lab course 300112 (mandatory)<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="48" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Report (45%)<br />Quizz(es) (5%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The lab course accompanies the General Electrical Engineering II (300102) lecture. The key concepts treated in the lecture will be highlighted by experiments (such as Fourier analysis, amplitudeand frequency modulation, signal processing,...).<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The 1st year labs will take place on Thursdays and Fridays, 14:15-18:30.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                 <b>This course is divided into the following sections:</b>&#13;
                                                                            </td>&#13;
                 </tr><tr><td class="tbdata">&#13;
                                                    <span>&#13;

                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this course we will apply techniques from signals and systems combined with random processes to study modulation and demodulation procedures with and without noise.<br />Based on these fundamentals of communications, we will address several aspects of binary data transmission up to band limited channels, multipath interference and channel equalization as a counter measure.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Quizz(es) (100%)<br />Home Work (0%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course gives an introduction to electronics and electronic circuits. Throughout the first part the operation principle and the application of diodes, bipolar junction transistors (BJT's), and field-effect transistors (FET's) will be discussed. Different electronic circuits will be analyzed and designed like operational amplifiers. In the second part the terminology and the concepts of digital electronics are introduced, including number systems and logic. The operation principles of logic gates, flip-flops, counters, shift registers and adders will be described. The student will be able to analyze and design simple logic circuits using tools such as Boolean Algebra and Karnaugh Mapping.<br />Topics:<br />Diode, BJT, FET, Inverter, Logic Gates, Shift Register, Flip Flops.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The goal of the lab course is to establish a basic understanding of electrical circuits and electronic components. The knowledge and understanding of Kirchhoff's laws, mesh and nodal analysis, and basic circuit theorems taught throughout the courses on general electrical engineering I and II is assumed. The goal will be accomplished by a combined approach of experimental and simulation experiments. The experiments will provide the students with practical experience and allow the students to relate the experiments to device and circuit models. Spice and OrCad will be used for the simulation of the basic components and circuits.<br />Topics:<br />RLC circuits, filters and resonators, diodes, pn-junctions and their application, bipolar junction transistors (BJT) and elementary transistor circuits including amplifiers, differential amplifiers and the basics of operational amplifiers, application of operational amplifiers MOS field effect transistors and their application in inverter circuits and elementary logical circuits.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This lab is on the one hand intended to directly accompany the corresponding DSP lecture in performing C and Matlab realizations of, e.g., transforms and digital filters. On the other hand it tries to give an insight into a system realization on a signal processor and FPGA platform. For signal-processor implementations, first tools are used to generate the DSP code followed by optimization of time-critical code segments. This means, learning DSP assembler programming will be part of the course. In the case of FPGA, tools will also generate the VHDL code, but essential VDHL properties will be taught, as well. Some of the experiments will be devoted to the communications field. The lab will thus as well serve as a counterpart for the communications lecture.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Basic concepts of discrete linear shift-invariant systems are emphasized, including sampling, quantization, and reconstruction of analog signals. Extensive coverage of the Z-transform, discrete Fourier transform, and fast Fourier transform is given. Discussion of digital filter design includes  impulse invariance, bilinear transform, and window functions. Practical filter implementations are discussed, including finite length register effects, roundoff noise, and limit cycles.  Attention is given to the use of digital filters for analysis and prediction of stochastic time series.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Microelectronics is the key enabling technology for almost all IT and electronic products and services. It is estimated that about 10\% of all EE engineers work in microelectronics industry and their suppliers, and a much larger percentage depends directly or indirectly on a basic knowledge of microelectronics technology and production methods. It is therefore the objective of the course to provide an overview of the field. Topics to be covered are: production and quality of semiconductor materials; IC manufacturing technology; unit processes (photolithography, dry and wet etching,<br />hot processes, layer deposition, assembly, testing) process integration, quality management, industrial engineering. In many of these topics, EE and CS competencies are applied. - A more thorough treatment of the subject on the key areas will be offered within the graduate program.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course is offered by all professors of Electrical Engineering jointly. The professors propose a number of research projects, which can be handled within the space of 6 weeks full time (or equivalent distributed time) and will be in the following areas:<br />Microelectronics, electronic devices, communication technology, systems reduction, quality management, photonics. The list of projects will be posted on the website. Students interested in particular projects should get in touch with the professor in charge of that project. As part of the project the students should prepare a final report (20 pages) and present the project in a seminar during the last 2 weeks of the semester.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        As the feature size of semiconductor devices continues to shrink at a staggering rate, the increasing degree of integration allows very complex digital systems to be realized on a single chip. Such systems can either be fabricated in application specific integrated circuits (ASICs) using very high scale integration (VLSI) techniques or implemented in programmable devices, such as field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). In both cases, very large designs are partitioned into a hierarchy of logical blocks, and by adhering to a set of standard design rules, the difficulty of integrating these blocks is dramatically reduced. The most popular approach is synchronous design with register transfer level (RTL) logic, but asynchronous designs are also possible.<br /><br />Although digital systems were traditionally designed at the schematic level, the current trend is towards hardware description languages (HDLs) that allow compact description of very complex hardware constructs. The appearance of sophisticated automatic hardware synthesis engines that implement logic directly from HDL have made HDLs the choice for new logic designs. Although the target language of this class is VHDL, other languages such as Verilog and SystemC apply the same design strategies. This course stresses the importance of viewing HDL as a way of describing real hardware, and not "just another programming language".<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Error correction codes (conventional codes, block codes, turbo codes etc.) and related combinatorial constructs play an important role in modern digital high data-rate transmission systems. This course will focus on theory, construction, and algorithms for error correction codes, and will highlight the application in communication systems and cryptography, for example.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course provides an overview of how medical technologies are developed and translated into clinical practise by way of active learning, such as web searching, hands-on experiments, and group activities. Case studies are provided to examine a number of diseases and possible technologies to diagnose or treat the diseases. Through these case studies, we will also pay attention to the safe use of technologies in medical practises and consider the legal, regulatory, sustainability, and ethical issues associated with the development of the medical technologies.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Circuits&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Circuits" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who complete this course will master the methods of analyzing linear electric circuits through the use of the basic laws of electrical engineering starting with Kirchhoffs laws and ideal circuit element models. Methods of analysis of circuits taught include node voltage and mesh current methods, superposition, and Thevenin/Norton transformations. These methods are first developed with resistive circuits and applied under dc conditions. Transients in first-order circuits are analyzed through the use of differential equations. After a description of the representation of sinusoidal waveforms by phasors, the methods developed earlier are used to study and analyze ac circuits. The theory of the electrical transformer is explained, and the next objective is to apply the laws of circuits to electric power systems. The concept of phasor power and its constituents, and the importance of power factor are taught.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        ATTENTION: This course is for Lafayette Students only.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        The course General Logistics II will provide a comprehensive overview of different areas, which are relevant for logistics performance. <br />Therefore, the course will address topics like human resources in logistics, supply chain management, environmental management, resource management for logistics, as well as customer requirements and service level management.
