                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Research Paper (30%)<br />Case Presentations (20%)<br />Attendence &amp; Participation (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course is intended to introduce students to different concepts of value generation and value measurement in a distribution logistics setting. In order to accomplish this, a general introduction to the generation of corporate value is given. This is followed by an examination of different value generation and earnings models of distribution logistics providers as well as corporate logistics departments. Particular attention is paid to the two dimensions of logistics value generation, "Service Excellence" (effectiveness based value generation) and "Cost Minimization" (efficiency based value generation). The major reasons why (and how) firms measure distribution logistics performance, to reduce operating costs, drive revenue growth and enhance shareholder value are examined during the lecture and by utilizing case studies.<br />The course is divided into two main parts. For one, students are expected to attend classes and complete a number of case studies in a group setting. The cases serve to get an in-depth look at the real life implications of distribution value generation and the impact that logistics has on corporate success. The cases also train the analytical and management decision making skills of the students.<br />In addition, students have to write a 12-15 page seminar paper. Topics for the paper will be individually assigned to the students by the instructor. The paper gives the students the chance to explore some of the topics discussed in class in more depth and from a scientific as well as practical perspective.<br />After the completion of the course students will:<br />- have a solid understanding of value generation and value measurement in a distribution logistics setting<br />- understand the different dimensions of the distribution logistics value proposition<br />- realize the accute importance of logistics value generation in order to gain long term sustainable competitive advantages<br />- be able to apply the learnings in a real world setting<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students are required to pay for course material provided by the instructor (ca.  EUR 12,50).<br /><br />Registration priority to ILME masterstudents!<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Presentation (40%)<br />Active Participation (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Many people only think of Marketing as selling and advertising. To be successful in the modern business environment marketing must be understood holistically as satisfying customer needs. Today, distribution as one of the marketing-mix tools is vital for brand success in the market. Distribution channels are business structures, reaching from the product origin to the final consumer, through which marketing professionals sell, transport, store, and deliver products and motivate, communicate with, and provide services for customers. Objectives of this course are the analysis of decisions, distribution channel behaviour and organization, distribution channel design decisions, distribution channel management decisions, market research tools for analyzing distribution channels and marketing logistics. From a branding perspective distribution can be seen as a part of the brand experience, therefore every brand has to deliver its brand promise continuously and consistently through every marketing channel.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Registration priority to ILME masterstudents!<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Increasing of containerisation has led to higher demands on the container terminals and thus fierce competition increase accordingly. Different terminals, with their unique combinations of liner services, yard layouts and equipment configurations, may require different terminal planning startegies. While an optimum yard plan can be found for each terminal planning strategy, it is interesting to know which strategy gives the best plan.<br /><br />The aims of the course are to develop jointly a realistic port terminal layout using a haptic planning table and to establish a basic understanding of underlying processes.<br /><br />Contents of the module:<br />-Introduction to terminal planning, demonstration of the main target of the module's outcome, and introduction to the usage of the haptic planning table<br />-Exercise: self study of training material and making familiar autonomously with the planning table's software, self study of dedicated literature, collection of relevant data based on proposed sources<br />-group work part I: Terminal planning<br />-group work part II: Preparation of presentation of group work and joint report, presentation of group work, hand-in of joint report<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Registration priority to ILME masterstudents!<br /><br />13.03., 13-18.30<br />14.03., 9-11.45<br />27.03., ganztägig (HH)<br />29.03., 9-12.45<br />09.04., 10-13.45<br />12.04., 9-11.45<br />13.4., 13.30-16.15<br />16.04., 9-11.45<br />[19.4., 9-11.45  Make-Up-Session  just in case]<br />27.04., 14-15.15<br /><br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  2.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 15&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will use simulation games for increasing the awareness of how own decision making impacts on the supply chain. It will focus on aspects concerning production logistic.  Furthermore, within the safe learning environment, the students can apply different logistic strategies for improving the flexibility and efficiency of the manufacturing and analyze the impact afterwards.<br />Learning objectives <br />This course aims at giving the students an opportunity to collect experience on how own decisions impact on the other stakeholders in a supply chain as well as within the own company. The students will apply different logistics strategies as well as methods supporting the decision making in order to:<br />	understand the main processes within the supply chain<br />	understand the impact of own behavior on the output<br />	develop and apply strategies for a more flexible manufacturing, reduction of stock and batch sizes, improving the internal transport and analyze the impact afterwards.<br />	Look at the consequences of make-or-buy decisions <br />	be aware of the role of communication and the information flow between the internal and external stakeholders<br />	be aware of how own decisions impacts on the other internal and external stakeholder<br />	apply different decision making methods and logistic strategies and analyze the impact this have on own and the overall result<br /><br />Audience and prerequisites: Master students of logistics, production engineering and industrial management. The students should know the basic principles of supply chain management and the objective of logistics, as well as standard logistic strategies, like Kan-ban, Just in Time. LIFO/FIFO etc. A short repetition of these strategies will be given. <br />Instructional plan: <br />The course uses a blended learning concept and the games will be played in different rounds, focusing on applying different methods and strategies.<br />This class will start with an introduction to serious games as learning tool and an introduction to the simulation scenario we will use, including role and task description and the objective of the different rounds.<br />After each round, the students and the facilitator will discuss the outcome of the game, the challenges and opportunities as well as looking at new strategies to be applied in the next round, in order to support the opportunities and overcome the challenges. The role based game offers opportunity for improving the flow of material and information within the production site, depending on the collaboration and communication abilities of the players.<br />The students will deliver a lab report 14 days after the last class<br /><br />Materials: <br />1.	Script<br />2.	Slides<br />3.	Game<br />4.	List of additional material<br />1.	Council of Supply Chain Management Professional: http://cscmp.org/<br />2.	Hoekstra, S. and Romme, J. (1992), Integrated Logistics Structures: Developing Customer Oriented Good Flow, McGraw-Hill, London <br />3.	Ballou, Ronald H. (2006)., The evolution and future of logistics and supply Chain management,  Produçao, v.16, n.3, p.375-386.<br />4.	Ballou, Ronald H., Business Logistics/ Supply Chain Management, 5th ed. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 2004 <br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Registration priority to ILME masterstudents!<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;

This course seeks to guide students during their studeis and to discuss matters related to the program.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        InfoSystems&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="InfoSystems" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="321524162905386" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  2.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 15&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Information and communication technology (ICT) plays an increasingly important role for logistics planning and control. This course introduces the information systems that support human dispatchers in their duties. An important foundation is the synchronisation of real-world material flows with their corresponding information flows by means of identification systems. Furthermore, logistics processes are highly distributed among departments (e.g. procurement, production, distribution) and even companies. Therefore, communication technology as a foundation for implementing distributed information systems is another topic.<br /><br />The objective of this course is to enable logisticians to communicate with IT professionals in designing information systems for logistics. To this end, a focus lies on modelling information systems with respect to processes, data, information, and knowledge. Furthermore, future developments in ICT that do not only incorporate information systems but also automated control are discussed. Finally, simulation is considered as a means to validate control systems and logistics strategies.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Registration priority for ILME masterstudents<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course is focused on the detailed analysis and evaluation of logistical processes for materials and production using specific range-oriented key data and throughput diagrams.<br />In the theoretical part we will discuss how to calculate key data to help identify irregular logistical processes and we will show different types of throughput diagrams and how to use them to evaluate industrial processes. We will consider historical data as well as current planning data.<br />In the practical part of the course we will analyze real data coming from a manufactoring company to learn how to use these methods to identify and evaluate weak points in the logistical processes. In addition, we will discuss possible solutions. <br /><br />Students are required to bring their own laptops.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Registration priority to ILME masterstudents!<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        IntroSAP&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Distribution as well as application of standard business software continually increases demanding for fundamental knowledge in handling and operating these softwares. Especially SAP standard software like SAP ERP for supporting and optimizing complex business processes is applied not only in big enterprises but also in small and medium-sized companies all over the globe. Accordingly, more and more firms expect students to have first experiences in SAP tools when they leave university. Current application requirements underline this trend.<br />This course offers students to gain and apply basic knowledge in the SAP ERP 6.0 software. SAP ERP is an integrated standard business software suite that represents business processes of all company departments such as Finance&amp;Accounting or Production. Via so-called modules in the software it maps all areas and enables the user to manage and operate according business in the system. That increases efficiency and effectiveness of these business processes, makes them more transparent and easier to communicate. <br />In the course, the SAP ERP system will be introduced including basic terms of the system like organizational units, master data, transaction data, and documents. Afterwards, students will be trained in using and handling the SAP ERP system. This comprises an overview about the graphical user interface, system functionality, navigation etc. Additionally, students will work with different modules and execute tasks like entering master data, booking business transactions, or approve and release orders. In a nutshell, this course provides a basic and general overview and understanding of the SAP ERP 6.0 software suite and thus increases the attractiveness of students towards the relevant industries.<br />The course will be conducted as a workshop based on specific course materials in form of slides, case studies, and accompanying literature. After a short presentation as introduction in the first session students will work on the case studies in small groups. A utilization of textbooks during the session and in self-study will help to refresh required general business knowledge that is essential for the course. <br /><br />At the end students are requested to give a presentation to one related department based on content of the course and the textbook.<br /><br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        ILME (MSc) students will be given priority in registration.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="15" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        50% Written Exam<br />20% Case study<br />10% Attendance<br />20% Computational Modeling &amp; Simulation Workshop <br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Port is a complex industry and plays a great role in the logistics chain. Port is often seen only as a terminal where containers and other cargo units are loaded and discharged. In fact, the roles of the port are very diverse and vary from how the port is organised.<br />Due to this complexity, it is very important to understand how the port according to different port models functions. Development plan of the port highly influences on the processes and services provided.<br />In this course, the fundamentals of port operations will be introduced. Exercises and workshops in a group working on a concrete case study enhance the understanding of the complexity in this industry.<br /><br />Aims of course<br />-	To apply methodologies to model a complex industrial cluster with the aim to identify key services and processes and to improve those <br />-	To introduce essential elements of ports covering their administration, management and operations<br />-	To introduce different port model<br />-	To explain role of port authorities<br />-	To introduce industries involved in ports<br />-	To introduce the importance of process modelling specifically in ports and generally in maritime logistics <br /><br />Learing outcomes / course objectives<br /><br />Professional competences: ability to manage complex systems <br />Methodological competences: ability to indentify, control and transfer process to other application areas <br />Practical competences: ability to work on a business case which is useful for the analysis work<br />Social competences: ability to work in a team<br />Personal competences: ability to identify the essentials in leadership<br /><br />Contents of the module<br /><br />1.	Introduction: Definition of the port, role of ports, services and different actors in ports<br />2.	Significance of port as transport node in logistics chain<br />a.	Freeport<br />b.	New customs procedure (and its impact)<br />3.	Port and waterway infrastructure (infrastructure usage by ships, terminals and other logistics entities)<br />4.	Port Operation Management (incl. Port Processes)<br />Case study of the impact of port development plan on the port processes<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The International Logistics Programs Research Colloquium above all provides a forum for students of the program to present and discuss their current research, in particular their master theses.<br />Its purpose is to familiarize students with concrete problems from the actual practice of international logistics. All professors who teach in the program as well as all graduate students of International Logistics may participate in the colloquium. It aims to strengthen the students understanding of logistics related issues and make them more aware of the problems encountered when applying theories and methods to concrete research topics. The colloquium offers students the opportunity to present their work to a wide audience, allowing them to get advice from fellow students and other participants involved. Thus the colloquium, in addition to individual tutoring by thesis supervisors, is an important part of the tutoring process.<br />Other contributions to the Research Colloquium may consist of lectures by Jacobs University professors or guest speakers. Students will learn to critically discuss and assess the advantages and problems of logistics-related methods and issues as well as the results of concrete research in the field.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Complex Analysis builds on the material taught in the undergraduate Complex Variables course. After a quick review of the most important results and concepts, some more advanced topics are covered. Possible subjects are Riemann Surfaces, Elliptic Functions and Modular Forms, Complex Dynamics, Geometric Complex Analysis, or Several Complex Variables. Which subjects are chosen will depend on the instructor and on the students interests.<br />This course may also provide an introduction to a specific area of research, leading to possible PhD thesis projects.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course assumes basic knowledge of measure and integration theory,<br />and of classical Banach and Hilbert spaces of measurable functions. Functional Analysis focuses<br />on the description, analysis, and representation of linear functionals and operators defined<br />on general topological vector spaces, most prominently on abstract Banach and Hilbert spaces.<br />Even though abstract in nature, the tools of Functional Analysis play a central role in applied<br />mathematics, e.g., in partial differential equations. To illustrate this strength of Functional<br />Analysis is one of the goals of this course.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The Seminar will treat modern applications of Mathematical Analysis to the world of Computation and Mathematical Modeling, with emphasis on the design and the theoretical foundation of numerical simulation algorithms and the derivation and justification of model hierarchies in the natural sciences and engineering. The interest ranges from modern techniques of data, signal, and image analysis to analytical and numerical algorithms for models governed by partial differential and integral equations. The concrete topics will change from semester to semester, and will be closely related to the research agendas of the instructors.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        BioThermKinSep&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Midterm Exam (30%, Mandatory)<br />Home Work (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course focuses on the thermodynamics and kinetics of structure formation and association of biomolecules, a theme of central importance for biological recognition. It includes a discussion of theoretical methods to describe thermodynamic driving forces for association and structure formation and how to analyze cooperative effects. The course is also intended to give a comprehensive overview on experimental methods to measure thermodynamic contributions and how to investigate the kinetics of biological processes at various time scales. In addition, separation methods that are based on differences in the physical properties of proteins and other biomolecules will be discussed in detail.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This semester (S2012) the course focus a bit more on the experimental methods and theoretical background to understand the biophysics of cellular membranes. The framework is still an introduction to systems, experimental and theoretical methods in biophysics.<br />The course should address biophysics interested MSc students from MoLife or NanoMol, but also motivated 3rd year BSc students. For some topics, a basic mathematical background is certainly needed.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Computational approaches to analyzing, understanding and predicting biological processes have developed rapidly in the last decade and have by now an important  role in virtually every fields of biological research. With these lectures we aim at highlighting  the current computational achievements in different areas of biology, their limits and possible future developments. Topics include: predicting protein structure from sequences, understanding genome evolution, simulating cells, simulating membrane transport with atomic resolution, predicting epidemic spreading of diseases and analyzing patterns of brain activity.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Cellular Biochemistry is an elective course for MoLife that is also accessible to third-year undergraduate students. It has fourteen sessions.<br />The course builds on the understanding of biological systems established in the undergraduate courses, Advanced Cell Biology I+II and Advanced Biochemistry and Molecular Biology I+II, or equivalent. Although a brief introduction will be given, graduate or undergraduate students who have no foundation in cell biology should consider attending Advanced Cell Biology prior to this course.<br />This is an intensive course, based on advanced textbooks, scholarly reviews, and recent research articles, that will take students to the cutting edge of a few select fields. The topics are a selection of complex and integrated systems from all areas of biochemistry and cell biology that change from year to year, and that are typically analyzed on all levels from their molecular mechanism to their cellular manifestations. They may include intracellular trafficking of proteins and lipids, synthesis and turnover of cellular components, regulation and signal transduction, and development and cooperation of cells in tissues.<br />The course will also provide and train skills that are needed to understand and critique published data.<br />Each subject is typically covered by:<br />- a lecture-style initial introductory overview by the instructor;<br />- a thorough discussion of selected topics that requires prior reading of review articles;<br />- student presentations of research papers including a detailed analysis.<br />Prior reading of the provided literature is essential, required, and relevant for the grade.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%, Mandatory)<br />Midterm Exam (30%)<br />Active Participation (20%)<br />Two quizzes (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Infectious diseases have always been and still are a major thread to our civilization. Knowledge of the molecular basis and mode of action of many pathogen-mediated diseases has sky-rocketed in the past decades. This half-semester course is meant to familiarize the student with a selection of infectious diseases, the microbial pathogens causing them, and potential ways to heal infected persons. Although this selection of diseases can by no way be comprehensive due to time constraints, some of the most important diseases will be dealt with. For advanced participants (i.e. those who previously took the 3rd-year undergraduate Biomed and Infection Biology course) particular problem tasks for some diseases will be given. Diseases and pathogens to be dealt with include: HIV, TB, candidiosis, Salmonella, toxoplasmosis, malaria, bacterial toxins, plant pathogens, and sexually transmitted diseases. A total of 13 lectures will be followed by a final examination in the 14th time slot. Additionally, a short mid term quiz will be held.<br /><br />Grading: <br />50% final examination<br />25% mid term<br />25% active participation<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this course, the most recent literature from molecular immunology and related fields is studied through detailed presentation and discussion. Emphasis is on the evaluation of the quality and novelty of the data, the stringency of the conclusions, and the contributions of the findings to the knowledge in the field. New avenues for research are discussed. Presentations of research from the Springer group may be added as appropriate.<br />The course is suitable for graduate students in MoLife who have a strong background in biochemistry and/or cell biology (e.g. those in the specialization area Cellular and Molecular Biology) but also for undergraduates from the BCCB major. In addition to lectures by the intructor, the students who attend the course present papers, possibly several times during the semester, upon which grading is based. Individual presentation training is provided. <br />This course is the continuation of the Literature Course Immunology I (course number 530641). That course is not a prerequisite, though, since the literature sources discussed in the two courses are independent of each other.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Prerequisites for undergarduate students only: Advanced Cell Biology I, II.<br />Prerequisites for graduate students: none.<br /><br />For registration please meet Prof. Springer. (Registration will be done manually by the Registrar's Office).<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;
                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Thomas Nugent</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        OrgCat&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="OrgCat" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Ten years ago only transition metal or enzyme mediated enantioselective catalysis were pursued. Organocatalysis is now a third option, providing competitive, as well as complemetary solutions for the synthesis of diastereo- and enantioenriched pharmaceutical drugs and natural products. The underlying premise is that low molecular weight chiral organic molecules can be designed and employed for the catalytic activation of archiral starting materials culminating in asymmetric bond formation. The catalysis concepts originate from Bronstedt acid and base chemistry and rely heavily on covalent activation and/or strong chiral counter ion effects. When bifunctional organocatalysts are used, weaker, noncovalent, attractive forces (notably hydrogen bonding) become important. Use of these and other steric and electronic design features allow chemists to control the trajectory, facial approach, and conformation of reacting chemical partners. Students interested in this course will feel comfortable with the material discussed in the first year of organic chemistry, and would like to strengthen and expand their understanding of those concepts regarding the stereocontrol (transition state analysis) that permits access to the advanced building blocks required for natural product synthesis.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;
</tr><!-- KG START --><!-- KG END --></table>";s:12:"appointments";a:27:{i:0;a:4:{s:4:"date";s:16:"Th, 2.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The graduate seminar exposes the students of the graduate program in Nanomolecular Science to actual developments in the field. The scientific content is provided via three routes: (i) The participants write essays on subjects designated by the instructor, which are based on own literature research. They also present their findings to the class in seminar talks. (ii) Faculty of the Nanomolecular Science program give short presentations. (iii) The instructor of record can also designate talks at Jacobs University by external speakers as mandatory for this seminar (e.g. chemistry and physics seminars, Wednesday colloquium) if they thematically fit into its scope.<br /><br /> In addition to the scientific content, the seminar pursues other important objectives. Through their own essays and presentations (i) students train to conduct literature research, to write scientific papers and to prepare and present scientific talks. The presentation of faculty research (ii) gives them an overview of research possibilities at Jacobs University and helps them select their lab rotations, and their MSc or PhD theses. Attendance of talks by external speakers (iii) exposes them to the current research carried out worldwide. Last but not least, the regular meetings of Nanomolecular Science graduate students and faculty helps to give the program an identity.<br /><br />Grading is based on attendance, the essay and the presentation. In the latter two, not only the scientific content but also the quality of presentation is graded.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Nanomol II&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Exam - first part (50%, Mandatory)<br />Exam - second part (50%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is the second in a series of two mandatory courses on Nanomolecular Science which provide a survey of the field, both from a chemical and physical point of view. The course will introduce the principal design of nanomolecular systems, their characteristic physical and chemical properties, principal functions and applications. The focus will lie on organic functional systems and on applications of nanotechnology in the physical sciences, mainly nanoelectronics. It thus complements the inorganic, material-related and methodological aspects covered in Nanomolecular Science I. Nanomolecular Science II is divided into two parts, one tought by a physicist and one by a chemist.<br /><br />The first part will cover topics such as carbon nanotubes and their electronic applications, single electron transistors, molecular electronics and nanomagnetism, surface functionalization and microfluidics, DNA nanotechnology and biomolecular motors.<br /><br />The second part will cover the basics of supramolecular chemistry including non-covalent interactions, aspects of experimental investigations of supramolecular systems (NMR and fluorescence spectroscopy), classes of supramolecular receptors (anion, cation and neutral species receptors), logical gates, programmed self-assembly and molecular devices and machines. It will cover natural as well as synthetic systems.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Due to the restructuring of the Nanomol courses this course actually discusses in its first part microscopy and scanning probe techniques including some microfabrication. The second part will be on inorganic nanosystems such as nanobeads and their physio/chemical properties.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The series of Nanomolecular Science Research courses (I, II) are mandatory for students enrolled in the Nanomolecular Science graduate program. During this series the students are exposed to a specific research area of nanoscience/nanotechnology  in-depth. For this the student is required to participate in the research activities of an IUB faculty member that participate in the Nanomolecular Science graduate program. Typically a continuous project defined by the supervising faculty member is conducted during the three consecutive Nanomolecular Science Research courses (I, II). The research can involve experimental and/or theoretical topics.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This Graduate level course is designed for physicist and students of neighboring disciplines, i.e. chemists and electrical engineers, with basic knowledge in solid state physics. It introduces in systematic order experimental methods for condensed matter analysis with special emphasis on methods with relevance to nanoscience. Where necessary special sample preparation methods are discussed together with the measurement principle and the measurement quantities and measurement accuracy. Methods discussed include basic methods, like x-ray diffraction, photo electron spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy, up to advanced complex machinery as e.g. high resolution techniques available at synchrotron radiation facilities.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        The CSE seminar is a public lecture series on Electrical Engineering. Lectures are given by faculty from the interdisciplinary research area "Information and Communication Science and Technologies"1, their research collaborators from all over the world, and by selected graduate students from the CSE graduate program.                                                         <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Herbert Jaeger</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Machine Learning A&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Machine Learning A" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The grading will depend on the structure of the seminar+project twin, and will be negotiated at the beginning of the semester. There will be only one grade for the seminar+project twin, which will be given in duplicates for the (officially) two courses seminar + project.<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The machine learning seminars will concentrate each on one theme connected<br />to the ongoing research of Prof. Jaeger, who will choose the topic he finds most fascinating<br />at the time when the seminar takes place. The topics might be only indirectly related<br />to machine learning proper. At the time of writing, the following themes would qualify and<br />can serve as examples: (i) motor control with neural networks, (ii) biological motor control,<br />(iii) optimal decision making under uncertainty, (iv) learning algorithms for stochastic systems,<br />(v) nonlinear system modelling: industrial applications, (vi) analyzing brain signals, (vii) the<br />challenge of complexity: what mathematics still cant capture.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar is a twin of the associated course "320444 Machine Learning Project A". Each is a corequisite of the other. <br /><br />The course homepage, where all communication and information is channeled, is <br /><br />http://minds.jacobs-university.de/teaching/MLFall11<br /><br />This page will go online shortly before the semester starts. <br /><br />At the time of writing (early January) it seems most likely that the topic of the seminar will revolve around "agent architectures" or "complex learning architectures". This is a large area with connections to cognitive science, machine learning, cognitive neuroscience, and robotics. The guiding question is, how can one model (or design, or program) large complex learning systems which exhibit traits of real-life intelligence -- as, for instance, robot control architectures, natural language understanding systems, game-playing systems... Very many approaches exist, some more formalized, other more empirically based, but none yet is satisfactory. The main scientific difficulty is the sheer complexity of such systems. Stay tuned! before the semester starts, more concrete announcements will be made available on the course homepage.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;
</tr><!-- KG START --><!-- KG END --></table>";s:12:"appointments";a:26:{i:0;a:4:{s:4:"date";s:17:"Mon, 6.                                                                                                         This seminar addresses trends and issues in database and Web technology,<br />focusing on the field of raster databases. Choice of topics will be streamlined with ongoing<br />research in the field, leading students to the forefront of technology. Among the areas likely<br />to be investigated are: study of applications in geo sciences, life science, and supercomputing<br />/ Grid computing; conceptual modelling issues; query and storage optimization techniques;<br />benchmarking raster databases.<br />Goal is to lead students to the frontiers of technology and confront them with active research by<br />stimulating active discussion gradually involving them into ongoing research (e.g., in project<br />collaborations).<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        The seminar covers a selected area of robotics in a significant depth.                                         <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;
                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Ph.D. Vladimir Viktorovich Molchanov</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        SemViz&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="SemViz" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        There are, in total, 5 presentations: a survey presentation, two presentations on selected approaches, and two project presentations. These are formal presentations. <br /><br />The overview presentations counts 30% to the overall grade. <br />The two selected topic presentations count 20% each to the overall grade. <br />The two project presentations count 15% each to the overall grade. The quality of the achieved results is not judged in this context. <br />As attendance is mandatory, each non-attendance without official excuse leads to taking 5% off of the final grade.<br /><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar covers selected topics of visualization. Scientific visualization deals with the visualization of data with a natural spatial interpretation such as computergenerated<br />data from numerical simulations (physics, chemistry) or measured data using scanning<br />or sensor techniques (medicine, life sciences, geosciences). Volume visualization methods<br />such as segmentation, surface extraction, and direct volume rendering for structured and unstructured<br />gridded as well as scattered data are being taught. These include techniques for<br />scalar field, vector field, and tensor field visualization. Information visualization deals with<br />the visualization of abstract data with no spatial interpretation such as graph- or network-based<br />data (life sciences, social sciences, computer networks) or multi-dimensional data (economics,<br />databases). Methods that tackle these visualization problems are being taught. The content<br />includes state-of-the-art and newly emerging approaches to scientific and information visualization.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Macroeconomics&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Macroeconomics" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 90&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="90" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course provides an introduction to the analysis of aggregate output, employment and economic growth and their relationship to the policy issues of unemployment, inflation and the balance of payments. Other topics include: national accounting; aggregate income and expenditure analysis; macroeconomic models of income determination; consumption, saving and investment functions; the role of money and banks; interactions between goods and money markets in equilibrium and disequilibrium situations.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who successfully complete this course will not receive credits towards the 180 ECTS-credits required for their BA degree from the course "Introduction to Economics" (course-no.: 930 201. These courses are mutually exclusive due to comparable content.<br /><br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM).<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="55" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Essay (30%, Mandatory)<br />Group Project 2 (30%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Group Project 1 (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Social Entrepreneurship - the practice of solving social problems by innovation and entrepreneurship - is a rapidly growing field. This is true both for the practice of social entrepreneurship as well as the study of social entrepreneurs. This course aims to provide students with an overview of what we know as well as an opportunity to explore what we still have to learn about social entrepreneurship and social innovation. In particular, the course will (a) review the major approaches, theories and concepts surrounding social entrepreneurship, (b) introduce students to a range of analytical tools from a spectrum of disciplines for understanding, analysing and assessing social entrepreneurship, and (c) enable them to explore concepts and tools by applying them to real-life case studies and examples of social entrepreneurship.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM).<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The GEM seminars, which are offered in the second and fifth semester, serve as a platform for interdisciplinary discussion related to the Global Economics and Management program. The seminars provide a forum for the presentation of talks on the complete range of topics of the program. Contributions come from within Jacobs University and from guest speakers; from academics as well as from practitioners. Presentations of specific topics will alternate with introductions to the fields of study from which these presentations originate. Participation in the two GEM seminars is mandatory for second- and third-year students of Global Economics and Management.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Public finance (also known as public economics) is the study of how public policy affects the allocation of resources and the distribution of income in the economy. In this course, you will learn how to use the tools of microeconomics and empirical analysis to answer such questions as: When should the government intervene in the economy? How might the government intervene? And, what are the effects of those interventions on economic outcomes?<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Active Participation (25%)<br />Presentation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br /><br />This course will cover the application of theoretical and empirical economics to the analysis of environmental and resource management issues. Specific topics will include global climate change, the relation between international trade and the environment, energy use, and the extraction of exhaustible and non-exhaustible resources. Cross-cutting these topics will be an emphasis on how economic analysis can contribute to contemporary policy debates.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Global Economics and Management (GEM), and Integrated Environmental Studies (IES)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br />- IES students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br />I WILL BE OBLIGED TO  GO ON A RESEARCH TRIP DURING THE TERM (MOST LIKELY TWO APPOINTMENTS). THOSE SESSIONS WILL TAKE PLACE THE 5TH OF MAY.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="60" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Inside Apple Paper (30%, Mandatory)<br />Research Journal Report (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory and participation is monitored. The instructor can award a bonus or malus to the final grade reflecting the student's attendance and participation.<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Organizing is a key management activity and organizations are both the context and the object of managerial work. This course introduces students to fundamental ideas on why organizations exist, how people behave in organizations, how organizations can be designed and changed strategically, and how they evolve in their environments. Managers also need to build and maintain inter-organizational relationships in projects, alliances, networks, supply chains and partnerships with various other organizations and in increasingly international contexts. The course covers classical principles of the division and integration of labor within and across firms. It also fosters a critical perspective on organizing as an ongoing creative, collective and contested practice that entails limitations for managerial control. Through project work, students learn what it means to be part of, and responsible for, contemporary organizations.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and in Module III "Management of Supply Chains and Networks" in the BSc program International Logistics. <br /><br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4) or spring 3 (semester 6). <br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br />The course is divided into Group A and Group B. The groups are taught together on Tuesdays (interactive lecture) and seperately on Thursdays (seminar/lab).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Dr. Philip Maloney</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Marketing&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Marketing" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 30&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Marketing covers a set of diverse practices that connect firms to their relevant markets. This course introduces the principal marketing decision-making areas known as the four Ps: product, price, promotion and place. Actual decisions on these parameters depend on how firms communicate with, and learn from, their customers who may be private consumers (B2C) or other firms (B2B) buying goods as well as services. Students learn that marketing strategies are also shaped by how firms marketing is integrated with other business functions, by the behaviors of competitors and partner firms, and by the values, needs, and standards in the firms environment. Marketing plays a key role in firms internationalization strategies and, building on many practical examples, the course familiarizes students with issues around foreign market entry, globalization and localization of marketing policies, and coordination within multinationals.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and for the IL module "Marketing and Strategies". <br /><br />This course will be offered for GEM students according to their mandatory table in their fall 2 (semester 3) semester.<br /><br />In Spring 2012  IL students (in particular those in the 3rd or 2nd year) will be given priority at registration . If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly. <br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Cont.Eur.Hist.&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Midterm Exam (40%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (5%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance (5%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course provides a broad overview of European history between the French Revolution and the end of the 20th century. As many topics in modern European history are addressed more extensively in more specific courses in modules II to IV, and since some of this history is familiar to most students from their high school history courses, the objective of this lecture is an introduction to a historical understanding and interpretation of major processes in those two centuries, and the emphasis therefore is rather on historical concepts and interpretations than on summarizing facts and events. As part of the World Regions and Civilizations module, the course will also try to sensitize students to the particular identity of a common European history, as opposed to the recent history of other world regions. On the other hand, students will learn about the diversity of European cultures and the most important "sub-regions" of modern European history. Topics include the transformation of Ancien Régimes and revolutionary change; the emergence of industrial societies and economies; the formation of nation-states and empire-building, modern political ideologies such as liberalism, nationalism, or socialism; war, dictatorship and the European dimensions of the Holocaust; post-war prosperity and environmental changes.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Participation, attendance, quizzes (50%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation, essay, paper (50%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The major economic transformation of the world that started in 18th-century England constitutes the core concern of this lecture. Since the field of modern economic history has witnessed a major transformation, with a significant expansion of both its subject area and its theoretical foundations, the classical process of the Industrial Revolution in technology and production will form an important starting point, but will not any more exclusively define this field. Attention will also be given to the preconditions of industrial growth in the agricultural and commercial economy of early-modern Europe. The history of economic processes has begun to include not just production, but also trade and consumption, as modern societies are increasingly defined as "consumer societies". In addition, the "cultural turn" has had its impact also on economic history, leading to a new emphasis on economic action, economic ideology, and the cultural implications of economic behavior. The lecture provides an overview over both classical and new topics in modern economic history, from early-modern beginnings to postwar economies after 1945 and issues of economic "globalization", and at the same time introduces students to different ways of conceptualizing past economies. The chief interest lies on Western economies, but their interrelations with local and dependent economies on the fringes of the Western world are also considered.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this semester the course focuses on the U.S. experience with economic growth and development. Starting with the first European settlements and the Colonial Era we will follow the ascendance of the U.S. from an agrarian economy to the worlds leading economic power.<br /><br />A mandatory introductory class will take place on Friday, February 3, when presentation topics will be introduced and distributed. At this session students must sign up for a presentation; no-shows and latecomers will not be considered. On February 10, students will present a first draft of an outline and an annotated bibliography for their research paper.<br /><br />Other important elements of this class are an essay and a research paper. Regular attendance is required and knowledge of the reading assignments will be reviewed through quizzes.<br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: International Politics and History (IPH), and Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS)<br /><br />- IPH students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;
