                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="31" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Presentation and Handout (35%)<br />Active Participation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance<br />Attendance is mandatory. You can be absent without an official excuse for two out of thirteen weeks. Any further absence without official excuse will lead to a downgrading of your overall grade by 0.33 per weekly absence.<br /><br />Grading Information: <br /> Active participation in class: a) oral contribution in discussions on texts of the seminar reader, and b) two short essays: one take-home essay, one in class-essay, together : 25%*<br /> Presentation and Handout: 35%<br /> Finals: 40%<br /><br />*there are three possible assessments regarding the oral participation: active participation (25%), moderate participation (16%), passive (no) participation (0%)<br /><br />Further grading information<br /> - 25% Active Participation : Attendance alone will not count significantly towards your participation grade.  Please take responsibility not only for doing the assigned readings each week but also for thinking carefully about those readings. What are the authors perspectives, and what are the main terms and arguments they are trying to convey? What do you find puzzling or surprising or disturbing about the readings? Be prepared to contribute your insights each week.<br />Two short essays (3-4 pages): You will be asked to briefly summarize the main aspects of the readings and comment critically on them.<br /><br /> - 35%  Presentation and Handout: The group presentation should be ca. 25 minutes long. The presentation will be followed by a discussion. A handout (about 2 pages) should list the major issues of the presentation, including the research question, your conclusions and proposals for discussion.<br /><br /> -  40%:  Finals (90 Minutes): About ten short knowledge questions,  related to the readings and the slides; answer one essay question (chosen out of two given essay questions).<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar builds on the previous lecture on nineteenth century international relations. It provides an opportunity for a more detailed study of international relations in a broad sense, i.e. including politics and transnational activities. The analysis of major conflicts and developments from the First World War to the end of the Cold War provides students with a critical understanding of the making of today's world. Through the close reading of available documents and the engagement with scholarly debates, the structure of international relations, its institutions and underlying forces, as well as major events which shaped politicians' behavior gain life. The course focuses on issues like the origins of wars, peace-making, collective security, crisis management, economic dependency and cultural diplomacy. It highlights features particular to the twentieth century; the potential of mass destruction and its realization, the role of ideologies, the expansion of international organizations, economic relations and an increasing but uneven linkage between societies all over the world. The tension between fragmentation and globalization, which we still see today, is thus explained in historical terms.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Birgit Mersmann</span>&#13;

                                                                        IntVisStud&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="IntVisStud" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Written Exam (40%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance, class participation and reading assignments (20%, Mandatory)<br />Poster Production and Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation and Discussion of a Selected Topic (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The proliferation of new media, in particular digital technologies, has enhanced the global circulation of images and drawn new attention to their power. In response to the increasing visual impact on culture and society, a Pictorial or Iconic Turn was proclaimed within the humanities, almost concurrently in the United States and in Europe. In order to study the "society of the spectacle" and the "politics of visibility" against the backdrop of the media industry and traditions of visual representation, new methodological and theoretical approaches have been developed and institutionalized that both include and transcend art history as a classical field of visual analysis. The course will survey and compare the most prominent research approaches in visual studies and picture theory, among them the Anglo-Saxon visual culture in relation to visual studies, the German "Bildwissenschaften," and the French philosophy of the image. The discussion of programmatic texts will be combined with practical visual analysis.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS).<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Presentation (30%)<br />Attendance and active participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        1. Attendance and active participation are obligatory (20%). Students who are absent without excuse for more than three times will not be credited.  <br />2. Presentation (30%): Every student has to present one of the texts of the READER in class. The presentation should be written down in a summary of 1000 words (due always one week after the presentation in class).  <br />3. Final exam (50%): The final exam will test your understanding of the material of the READER as well as the things you have learned in class.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course introduces the basic notions of a systematic reflection on language. Language is considered on its three levels of manifestation, as a universal, particular (historical, societal) and individual activity. On the universal level, the fundamental functions of language are communication and the creation of thought (cognition). Language acquisition (and the evolution of languages) is the implementation of an innate faculty in different cultural contexts. Hence language does not come as one universal language but in the diversity of the historical languages that are as many "views" of the world and not only different sounds. The universal rules of the human language faculty and the particular historical rules of the human languages form the basis for the individual linguistic production, the creation of utterances and texts (discourse). <br />After a look on the general functions of language and the different actions that can be performed linguistically (speech acts), we will consider the fundamental structural dimensions of language (its articulatory structure). The linguistic diversity of mankind as well as the interior diversity of what we are normally used to regard as "one" language (dialects, sociolects, registers) will lead us to the linguistic production of individuals. Linguistic diversity is the reason for the necessity of translation. The societal character of speech implies a political dimension of linguistic production and hence a dependence on power structures which influence the form of individual discourse. <br />Special attention is given to the aesthetic function of discourse and to language as literature. Recent theories on the origin of language suggest that the gestual-visual system of the human being is deeply connected with its phonetico-acoustic language system. In our culture language manifests itself not only as a sound phenomenon but also or sometimes primarily in a second, visual, form of linguistic creativity, in writing. Literature is the most developed manifestation of language in our culture. Written i.e. visual language leads to a consideration of the relation of language and discourse to visual symbolic forms.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS).<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Since the seventies of the 20th century religious communities are spreading rapidly on a global scale: not hierarchical institutions of church, mosque and synagogue, but voluntary associations. Laymen establish various forms of religious associations in the public realm. External circumstances accelerate that trend. Pressures from globalization compel the classical nation state to turn over public services to the market and to private actors. Religious associations are claiming responsibility for the well-being of the community and become providers for most of these services (education, media, welfare, medical care, legal arbitration and economic development); due to this trend their social capital becomes crucial to contemporary civil society. <br />In the West religious communities since long have received aid from the nation state when assisting needy people. In the Middle-East the state as administrative apparatus did never monopolize public services; here religious associations were solely responsible. In the diaspora Muslim labour migrants are establishing centres for social services on their own along with their ritual places. Due to technologies of communication and travelling their associations remain part of transnational networks. In regions and times of crisis these religious communities are creating armed wings to protect their territory. This explains new types of religious violence. Today Jewish, Christian and Muslim associations operate independently of the state and sometimes even in competition with it. This development imbues familiar issues as mission or conversion with new meanings: the inclusion in social networks. <br />Voluntary associations are the matrix for post-traditional types of religiosity. Pentecostalism, Fundamentalism, Esotericism, Apocalypticism, Kabbalah, Islamism do have their roots in religious history, but they derive persuasive power from their ability to define the situation of human beings in the present world and to give them a place in a new kind of community.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS).<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Presentation and Summarizing Essay 1 (35%)<br />Presentation and Summarizing Essay 2 (35%)<br />Attendance and Active Participation (30%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Exploring the notion of treating all artworks as texts, the crux of this seminar lies in exploring how theories have reinterpreted and in their way performed texts or made texts perform for and beyond a particular era, be it Antiquity, Modernity or Postmodernity. <br />In doing so, texts created as illustrations of particular theories or vice versa, such as automatic writing (écriture automatique) and the cut-up technique will be examined in order to highlight the interaction between theories and literature. Furthermore, the intermedial references incorporated by texts, including the more general use of images and the attempt to incorporate specific media like photographs or radio programs will be used to trace the role of intermediality (even before the academic popularization of the term). Finally the inclusion of key texts on psychoanalysis, gender and queer theory will enable exploring the ways in which literary theories can merge with cultural and social theories. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course may be taken as an elective by students of all majors (including ICS majors).<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Research Paper (40%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance, Class Participation and Reading Assignments (20%, Mandatory)<br />Poster Production and Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation of a Selected Topic (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        From the outset of the European Renaissance, Western visual art has experienced extraordinary dynamics of modernization and reformulation. Driven by inventiveness and originality as key concepts of modern aesthetics, Western art has run through a great number of epochs, styles and genres from the 15th to the 20th century, climaxing in the rapid succession and partial synchronicity of the avant-garde movements. This enormous change on the historical axis was cross-fertilized by topographical change resulting from intensive intercultural encounters of Western with non-Western art. The course focuses on the points of intersection between the historical and topographical axis of renewal and redefinition with regard to both Western and non-Western art. It will trace and investigate the impact of Non-Western art on Western art and discuss processes of transculturation, be it the "renaissance" effect of Antiquity and Oriental optical theory on the invention of the panel painting, the influence of Chinese and Indian art on the formation of Baroque and Rococo art, that of Japanese art on impressionism, or African Primitivism on Fauvism and Cubism. Vice versa, it will explore how the impact of Western art reshaped and dynamized non-Western art. These cross-cultural investigations will be embedded in a theoretical framework, including concepts of inter- and transculturality, translation studies and postcolonial theory.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS).<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Mod-Econ-Hist&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Mod-Econ-Hist" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Participation, attendance, quizzes (50%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation, essay, paper (50%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The major economic transformation of the world that started in 18th-century England constitutes the core concern of this lecture. Since the field of modern economic history has witnessed a major transformation, with a significant expansion of both its subject area and its theoretical foundations, the classical process of the Industrial Revolution in technology and production will form an important starting point, but will not any more exclusively define this field. Attention will also be given to the preconditions of industrial growth in the agricultural and commercial economy of early-modern Europe. The history of economic processes has begun to include not just production, but also trade and consumption, as modern societies are increasingly defined as "consumer societies". In addition, the "cultural turn" has had its impact also on economic history, leading to a new emphasis on economic action, economic ideology, and the cultural implications of economic behavior. The lecture provides an overview over both classical and new topics in modern economic history, from early-modern beginnings to postwar economies after 1945 and issues of economic "globalization", and at the same time introduces students to different ways of conceptualizing past economies. The chief interest lies on Western economies, but their interrelations with local and dependent economies on the fringes of the Western world are also considered.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this semester the course focuses on the U.S. experience with economic growth and development. Starting with the first European settlements and the Colonial Era we will follow the ascendance of the U.S. from an agrarian economy to the worlds leading economic power.<br /><br />A mandatory introductory class will take place on Friday, February 3, when presentation topics will be introduced and distributed. At this session students must sign up for a presentation; no-shows and latecomers will not be considered. On February 10, students will present a first draft of an outline and an annotated bibliography for their research paper.<br /><br />Other important elements of this class are an essay and a research paper. Regular attendance is required and knowledge of the reading assignments will be reviewed through quizzes.<br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: International Politics and History (IPH), and Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS)<br /><br />- IPH students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Sens-Perc&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Sens-Perc" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
                                                <input type="hidden" name="sws" value="3" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Pioneering work on sensation and perception started in the 19th century and through the years, perception has remained a major focus of Psychology. Sensation refers to the process of detecting a stimulus or a stimulus property in the environment. It is the necessary collection of information about the world from which perceptions will be made. Perception refers to the way in which we interpret the information that is gathered by the senses. The process of perception can not be understood while ignoring the known physiology of the sensory systems that underlies the perceptual process. The course covers both physiological explanations for phenomena of perception and more cognitive aspects of the perceptional process, for which a physiological explanation might be available in the future. <br />This lecture covers the following topics:<br /><br />-  Methods of investigation: Phenomenological method; psychophysical methods such as methods of limits, method of constant stimuli, magnitude estimation, and basic ideas of signal detection; psychophysical measures such as absolute threshold, difference threshold, adaptation; Fechner's law, Weber's law, Stevens' power law.<br />-  Visual perception: The visual stimulus, the structure of the eye, neural processing including basic neural circuitry, and information flow and organization in the brain; perception of objects and models of object perception such as the Gestalt approach, feature integration theory (Treisman), recognition-by-component model (Biederman), Marr's computational approach; perception of depth, monocular depth cues, binocular depth cues; perception of color and models of color perception such as trichromatic theory, opponent-process theory; perception of movement, motion sensing systems such as image-retina system, eye-head system, corollary discharge theory; perceptual constancies such as color constancy, size constancy, lightness constancy, shape constancy; and phenomenon such as visual illusions.<br />-  Auditory perception: The sound stimulus, the structure of the ear, neural processing in the cochlea and auditory nerve; the experience of sound (loudness, pitch, timbre); perception of simple tones and complex sound; models such as Bekesy's Place Theory; localization of sound.<br />-  Touch and pain: The cutaneous stimulus; the skin and its different receptor systems; active versus passive touch; pain and pain relief, such as analgesia and endogenous opiates, placebo.<br />-  Smell and taste: The olfactory stimulus, the olfactory system, the taste stimulus, the taste system; pheromones; taste quality; flavor.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="10" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course complements the Lecture on Sensation and Perception. It provides first hands-on experience with techniques, methods, and experimental tasks that are typical for psychological research on perception.<br />The course focuses on psychophysical methods which are applied in the behavioral and neurosciences. <br />Students learn to set up their experiments in MATLAB (or other languages if desired by the group but no support will be provided in that case), collect data and analyze them according to modern techniques.  Topics are closely related to the lecture. <br />Projects are run in groups of two. The participants of the course are expected to serve as their own experimental subjects in all experiments. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The class is restricted to maximal 10 Students. CPN majors have priority, followed by ISCP students.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attention research seeks to understand how attention allows and affects detection, perception and encoding of information, which algorithms underlie attentional functions and how those are implemented in the human brain.  The course focuses on classic and current issues within the field of attention research.<br />The course includes the following topics:<br />* Seminal past and current theories and models of attention<br />* Research methods and paradigms to study attention; attention tests<br />* Alerting, sustained attention, divided attention, selective attention, joint attention<br />* Involuntary versus voluntary attention, attentional control<br />*Overt attention: exploring the world with saccadic eye movements<br />* Attention across modalities<br />* Delopment of attentional functions<br />* Disorderrs of attention; impact of brain injuries on attention<br />* Neuronal networks of attention in the brain<br />* Practical applications of attention resea<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Decision making may be defined as intentional and reflective choice in response of perceived needs. Decision making and decision theory are broad and complex areas of great theoretical interest and practical impact in many fields. Decision making has been studied, e.g., in philosophy, mathematics, statistics, economy, biology, sociology, psychology, marketing, psychiatry, organizational behaviour, political science, anthropology, and many more, for some of these disciplines in more than two centuries. <br />The following topics are covered in this seminar:<br />-	Basic concepts: Utility, preference, uncertainty, prediction and interference (judgment), evaluation, and choice.<br />-	Prescriptive (normative) theories: Subjective expected utility (SEU), prospect theory, sign - and rank dependent utility; cumulative prospect theory.<br />-	Descriptive theories: Decision making under certainty; random utility models, elimination by aspects (EBA) <br />-	Decision making under risk / uncertainty: Structural models; Hammond's social judgment theory; Brunswik's lens model; Anderson's information integration theory (functional measurement- process theories contingency model; cost/benefit model (adaptive decision maker; criterion dependent choice model; decision field theory.<br />-	Practical issues: Improving decisions and avoiding decision traps.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;

                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Arvid Kappas</span>&#13;

                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Emot-Motiv&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Emot-Motiv" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;

                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 35&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="35" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Emotion and motivation are central to our own experience of the world and strongly influence the role we play in it. Emotion and motivation interface with almost all areas of psychology and are also highly relevant in connected domains. Terms such as emotion, mood, temperament, but also motivation are often used in ways that reflect our layman's understanding of these phenomena, but that does not take into account the extensive history of scientific research into these concepts. <br />This course explores the history and tradition of scientific research on emotion and motivation. The course is to provide students with a solid understanding of the competing theoretical approaches at different levels, ranging from biological and neuroscience approaches to social and cultural concepts. In consequence the successful participants shall have the foundations required to analyze the strengths and weaknesses of applying such concepts various contexts, including in empirical research as well as in various applications. Lastly, they shall be informed of current debates and trends in emotion and motivation research<br />Major theoretical approaches will be presented for emotion and for motivation. In each case there will be an emphasis on critical analysis and discussion of the premises and inconsistencies of the theories in the light of empirical data. The work of specific researchers or specific methods (e.g., measurement of facial activity) will be pursued in more depth.<br />Major theoretical approaches to emotions:<br /><br />-  Darwinian perspective on emotions. <br />-  Evolutionary basis of emotions and their expressions: Jamesian Perspective of emotion.<br />-  Function of physiological changes associated with emotion: Cannon critique of specificity of physiological patterning; mixed models, specifically the Schachter-Singer theory of emotion and associated concepts, such as excitation transfer.<br />-  Cognitive perspective of emotion: Origin of the modern appraisal construct in the approaches by Arnold and Lazarus, as well as modern multidimensional concepts of appraisal (e.g., Frijda, Smith, Scherer, Roseman); the relationship of cognition and emotion will be discussed particularly in the light of the Lazarus-Zajonc debate; multiple levels of processing.<br />-  Social-Constructivist Perspective: Different levels of social influence on the definition, experience, and expression of emotions will be discussed (e.g. Averill's theory); display rules, feeling rules, and social schemata of physiological responses.<br /><br />Major theoretical approaches to motivation:<br /><br />-  History of the motivation concept<br />-  Biological approaches: Drive concept; examples such as hunger, thirst; physiological underpinnings.<br />-  Behavioural approaches: Learning theory in relation to motivation (Pavlov, Thorndike, Garcia); innate vs. learned behaviour; species-characteristic stereotyped behaviour.<br />-  Cognition and emotion: Goals as knowledge structures<br />-  Motivation and social behaviour: Sociobiology, evolutionary psychology. Cultural perspectives<br />-  Interaction between emotion and motivation<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Soc-Neuro&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Soc-Neuro" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Social Neuroscience assumes that the mechanisms underlying mind and behaviour will not be fully explicable by a biological or a social approach alone. Hence, the interactions of different levels of organization, ranging from hormonal and biochemical factors, to the central and peripheral nervous systems, the endocrine and the immune systems, individual differences in behaviour, interpersonal interactions, and social and cultural moderators are the main focus of study. None of these levels is considered the best level of analysis for the understanding of human or animal behaviour. The students shall understand the rationale of and challenges for multi-level analyses and become familiar with examples of such approaches relating to different psychological concepts. This course provides arguments that social and biological approaches are complementary rather than antagonistic. Specifically it will address:<br /><br />-  Philosophical issues regarding the mind-body relationship.<br />-  Basic concepts of the psychophysiological approach.<br />-  Social Neuroscience as an extension of the psychophysiological approach.<br />-  Multilevel integrative analyses of social behaviour.<br />-  Introduction to the relative functions and structure of autonomic and somatic nervous systems in relationship to the central nervous system.<br />-  Social cognition and the brain: Basic processes, specific processes, such as the self, perceiving others, social information processing; description of a module in human extrastriate cortex specialized for face perception; voice-selective areas in human auditory cortex; the human amygdala in social judgment. <br />-  Social Neuroscience of motivation and emotion.<br />-  Social Neuroscience of attitudes and preferences: For example event-related potentials as indicators of negativity bias; face elicited event-related potentials and tomography analyses of affective attitude. <br />-  Biology of social relationships and interpersonal processes: Basic processes, specific processes such as attachment, personal ties, affiliation and sexuality, aggression and social order, individual differences in social behaviour.<br />-  Social influences on biology and health (. e.g., psychoneuroimmunology)<br />-  Problems of the Social Neuroscience concept.<br />-  The difficult relationship of social and biological approaches in psychology.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Attitudes&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Attitudes" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="40" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Presentation (40%)<br />Quizz(es) (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attitudes and social cognition are core topics of social psychology. An attitude is a representation summarizing an individuals evaluation of an object. Attitudes often combine feelings (affect), inclinations to act (behaviour), and beliefs (cognition). From a laypersons perspective, one might think that an attitude is stable and, when needed, can be retrieved like a stored document: We know whom we love, we know what we like and this will not change that easily. Social Psychological research challenged this notion by providing empirical evidence reflecting the fact that people do not read up their attitudes from an internal meter: Rather, attitudes are malleable and susceptible to various context influences. Given that this is the case, the measurement of attitudes needs a scientific training. It is important to know the methods available to assess peoples attitudes and the pros and cons of these methods. The context-sensitivity also opens avenues for change. Thus, for example, undesired attitudes leading to unhealthy behaviour can be changed if one understands their nature. One object of cognitive representations which is of particular interest in social psychology, are social objects, mainly other people and groups. The structures and processes involved in forming representations of social objects are the topic of social cognition research. The seminar will provide students with an overview of the main methods, approaches, and findings from research on attitudes and social cognition, and specifically cover the following aspects:<br /><br />-  Historical developments in attitude research<br />-  The concept of attitudes<br />-  The measurement of attitudes: Classic, explicit measures (e.g., questionnaire methods) and implicit measures (e.g., reaction time        measures).<br />-  The origin of attitudes<br />-  Situational influences on the construction of attitudes.<br />-  How attitudes can influence behavior and vice versa<br />-   Attitude change and persuasion<br />-  What is social cognition: Representations and evaluations about social objects<br />-  (Automatic) activation of knowledge in social cognition<br />-  Social cognition as co-cognition: Sharing representations with social subjects<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP) and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Presentation (40%)<br />Quizz(es) (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        	Quizzes: There will be no midterm or final exam. Instead, in the beginning of several sessions we will do quizzes (taking about 10 minutes each) consisting of multiple-choice and open-ended questions. Quizzes will be conducted at the beginning of class (sharp!), so if you arrive late, you might be unable to participate or will at least have less time to complete them! All quizzes will be summed up and make up 40% of your final grade. The quizzes will take place on February 21st, March 15th, April 17th and May 8th. <br />	Presentation: In groups of 2 or 3, students should prepare and give a presentation as outlined in the syllabus (40% of the final grade). You will be able to sign up for a session of your choice by a doodle-poll which will be opened after session 2 (February 7th) and will be closed after class on Thursday February 9th at 12.00.  Students who fail to submit their choice by the given deadline will be assigned a week and notified of the date of presentation by email. If there are more students or student groups than weeks of the semester, some students may be requested to hand in a written report instead of giving an oral presentation. <br />	Active participation in class (20 % of your final grade). <br />Students will receive .5 point for every session they attend (adding up to a total of 14 points). An extra 6 points can be earned by active participation in class. Active participations does not merely mean physical presence at the sessions. Rather, it means contributing to the ongoing discussions, on the basis of the required readings and critically evaluating them (10%) and participation in exercises and activities (10%). If students are repeatedly late for class or leave early without a valid excuse, this will also affect their attendance scores. In accordance with Jacobs University policies, the only accepted reason for absence is illness  supported with a doctor's certificate. <br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Social influence takes place when people change their behaviour caused by real or imagined pressure from others. For instance, we sometimes buy things which we do not really need or even do not want to buy just because we fall prey to a clever advertisement or a smart salesperson. We sometimes behave in certain ways only because others around us do the same thing. Understanding when and why such things happen is the goal of this seminar. <br />Social psychologists have considered three major categories of social influence: Conformity, compliance, and obedience. Conformity involves changing one's behaviour to match the responses or actions of others, to fit in with others around. Compliance refers to the act of changing one's behaviour in response to a direct request. Obedience is a special type of compliance that involves changing one's behaviour in response to a directive from an authority figure. <br />This seminar explores direct and indirect strategies of social influence. In particular, strategies that make use of the following principles will be discussed:<br /><br />-  The norm of reciprocation: This rule says that people should try to repay, in kind, what another person has provided them. <br />-  Commitment and consistency: Once they make a choice or take a stand, individuals will encounter personal and interpersonal pressure to behave consistently with that commitment.<br />-  Social proof: People tend to view a behaviour as correct in a given situation to the degree that they see others performing it. <br />-  Liking: People prefer to say yes to requests of others who they know and like. <br />-  Authority: People sometimes obey to authority figures and do things they would never have done without the influence of authorities. <br />-  Scarcity: Opportunities seem more valuable when they are less available, and are, therefore more likely taken. <br /><br />While this seminar primarily focuses on theoretical explanations and basic research findings in the field of social influence, the implications for various applied settings will be discussed. These include, for instance, advertisement design and consumer behaviour, negotiations in business and oratory techniques in law settings.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="40" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Discussion Participation (30%)<br />Reading Presentation (30%)<br />Term Paper (30%)<br />Attendance (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The globalization of the business environment is accompanied by an increasing number of cross-cultural interactions in the workplace. This course deals with the question of how culture influences behavior in organizational settings, especially the effect of culture on management from a predominantly psychological perspective, and provides the essential concepts for global cross-cultural management. <br /><br />Starting from describing/comparing national cultures, and defining organizational culture, the intermediate mechanisms for the influence of culture on organizational behavior are explored using psychological concepts. Organization relevant factors such as organizational structure, workgroup/team, motivation, etc. will be illuminated in a cultural context. Based on the analysis of cultural environment and embedment, cross-cultural managerial activities will be elaborated in the process and behavior of decision making, leadership, communication, and negotiation across cultures. Further implications for international management, inter alia, for Human Resource Management are to be discussed as well. <br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Attitudes&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="40" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Presentation (40%)<br />Quizz(es) (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attitudes and social cognition are core topics of social psychology. An attitude is a representation summarizing an individuals evaluation of an object. Attitudes often combine feelings (affect), inclinations to act (behaviour), and beliefs (cognition). From a laypersons perspective, one might think that an attitude is stable and, when needed, can be retrieved like a stored document: We know whom we love, we know what we like and this will not change that easily. Social Psychological research challenged this notion by providing empirical evidence reflecting the fact that people do not read up their attitudes from an internal meter: Rather, attitudes are malleable and susceptible to various context influences. Given that this is the case, the measurement of attitudes needs a scientific training. It is important to know the methods available to assess peoples attitudes and the pros and cons of these methods. The context-sensitivity also opens avenues for change. Thus, for example, undesired attitudes leading to unhealthy behaviour can be changed if one understands their nature. One object of cognitive representations which is of particular interest in social psychology, are social objects, mainly other people and groups. The structures and processes involved in forming representations of social objects are the topic of social cognition research. The seminar will provide students with an overview of the main methods, approaches, and findings from research on attitudes and social cognition, and specifically cover the following aspects:<br /><br />-  Historical developments in attitude research<br />-  The concept of attitudes<br />-  The measurement of attitudes: Classic, explicit measures (e.g., questionnaire methods) and implicit measures (e.g., reaction time        measures).<br />-  The origin of attitudes<br />-  Situational influences on the construction of attitudes.<br />-  How attitudes can influence behavior and vice versa<br />-   Attitude change and persuasion<br />-  What is social cognition: Representations and evaluations about social objects<br />-  (Automatic) activation of knowledge in social cognition<br />-  Social cognition as co-cognition: Sharing representations with social subjects<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social and Cognitive Psychology (ISCP) and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br />- ISCP students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;
                                                        <p>&#13;

                                        Seminar&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Civ.Netw./Soc.Cap.&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Civ.Netw./Soc.Cap." /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
                                                <input type="hidden" name="sws" value="3" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 30&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Various written assignments (50%)<br />Active Participation (25%)<br />Presentations (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar has mandatory attendance. Beyond that students will be graded based on <br />participation (25%), presentations (25%), and various written assignment (position papers and a written exam, 50%). This is a seminar, which means that attendance AND participation is important and that students are expected to prepare for each meeting. Each student will do a number of presentations (the exact number to be determined when the number of participants is known). In the presentations, you will be graded based on academic content, presentation skill, and contribution to the seminar discussions.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The market, the state, and the other macro-institutions discussed in modules I and II are embedded in social structures at the micro-level. This seminar examines the importance of personal trust, relational networks, and social capital for the functioning of the larger structures of society. It explains how apparently 'good' structures can fail in the absence of adequate social support, and how, on the basis of civic networks and social capital, citizens can work around, and change apparently 'bad' structures.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The concept of social capital is one of the key concepts in the social sciences. The concepts popularity stems from its wide-ranging application to social, economic and political problems in modern and developing societies. However, the scholarly debate on social capital reveals multifaceted literatures that span individual and collective approaches including some attempts to bridge the two. Depending on the realm of application the concept and theory of social capital has various meanings. Social and civic networks, as well as network architecture and dynamics, are central elements in social capital theory. We shall discuss applications of these concepts and their relevance for real world phenomena. <br />This seminar aims at making students familiar with 1) the conceptual and theoretical foundation of social capital, including classical origins 2) the measurement of social capital, 3) the sources of social capital, 4) and the outcomes of social capital at individual and collective levels. The presentation of social capital in this course is firmly grounded in a social networks and civil society approach.  In the seminar we shall discuss the different understandings of social capital and how they relate and differ. Additionally, we will bridge to fundamental questions of cooperation, reciprocity, trust, participation, status attainment, mobilization, and community. <br /><br />This class makes use of Turnitin for all written submissions (position papers and written exam). Please make sure you have an account (www.turnitin.com) and that you are accustomed to the system. <br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="90" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This seminar continues the analysis of the market. It asks why in market economies, not all economic transactions take place within the market. Why are some transactions moved outside of the market and coordinated hierarchically within business firms? The seminar examines both the internal organization and management of business firms and their external behavior. The topics covered include the economics of transaction costs, agency theory, elementary game theory, competitive advantage, strategy formation, and strategic pricing.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who successfully complete this course will not receive credits towards the 180 ECTS-credits required for their BA degree from the course Fundamentals of International Business (032 201). These courses are mutually exclusive due to comparable content.<br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB) and International Logistics (IL).<br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Midterm Exam (30%)<br />Presentation (30%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Mass media and communication networks permeate almost all aspects of contemporary societies. This lecture provides an overview of the more traditional forms of one-to-many communication by mass media and the more recent forms of one-to-one and many-to-many communication facilitated by new technologies, such as the internet. It introduces students to key issues and concepts in communication science, and reviews 'classic' studies in order to illustrate the co-evolution of media systems and media theory.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="81" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Poster (40%)<br />Presentation (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The production, distribution, presentation, and use of media is an important determinant of the size, density, development, innovative energy and adaptability of human groups, societies and cultural zones. Although modern media transcend national borders, distinct national and regional media cultures remain. This seminar compares media cultures across the major regions of the world: Europe, the United States, Latin America, Africa, and the Asian Pacific. It analyzes the structural setting of mass communication systems, and examines their cultural forms and content.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB) , and Global Economics and Management.<br /><br />Group A: GEM and IPH students preferred in registration<br />Group B: IRB and ISS students preferred in registration<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />As this course could not be offered in spring 2011 it is also mandatory in spring 2012 for 3rd year ISS, IRB and GEM students.<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Active Participation (25%)<br />Presentation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br /><br />This course will cover the application of theoretical and empirical economics to the analysis of environmental and resource management issues. Specific topics will include global climate change, the relation between international trade and the environment, energy use, and the extraction of exhaustible and non-exhaustible resources. Cross-cutting these topics will be an emphasis on how economic analysis can contribute to contemporary policy debates.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Global Economics and Management (GEM), and Integrated Environmental Studies (IES)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br />- IES students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br />I WILL BE OBLIGED TO  GO ON A RESEARCH TRIP DURING THE TERM (MOST LIKELY TWO APPOINTMENTS).                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="35" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Essay (25%)<br />Presentation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course aims to characterize the "transition" to a sustainable and low-carbon energy world. The course will explain in detail the policy topics on renewable (or otherwise low-carbon) energy sources and sustainable energy use (aka energy efficiency) and other policies to achieve lowcarbon energy supply. (eg. CO2 emission trading). The course will rely on theories from economics, management, political science, sociology and psychology where applicable to explain and thereby prepare students to critically assess sustainable energy policy.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is mandatory for students choosing the "Energy Policy and Technology" specialization in the BSc program Integrated Environmental studies. <br /><br />- IES students wishing to take the "Energy Policy and Technology" specialization should register for this course in Spring 2 (semester 4). <br /><br />Students in the above mentioned cohort will be given priority at registration.  If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        GlobalDemography&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Since people count demographers count people. Findings in demography are of interest to politicians, business people, public and to a wide range of sciences. Population questions occupy a central position in the research of economists, sociologists, geographers, historians, environmental scientists, and biologists. In this introductory lecture students will learn how global patterns of mortality, fertality and migration have altered and will change population development worldwide. The course focuses on crucial demographic contents and on formal techniques to make use and sense of demographic data. <br />We start out with a "thick" description of historical and global trends and contemporary demographic patterns. Then we get to know and to use measures and methods of demography like rates, population growth, age standardization, decomposition methods, mortality, fertality, and migration analysis. An introduction into standard life table techniques with aggregate and micro data will follow. We end with some population projections and their consequences for future societies.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="35" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Research Paper (50%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance (10%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Democracy is both a normative ideal and an empirical type of political governance. This seminar explores both dimensions. It is divided into three parts. The first part, "What is democracy?", deals with conceptual foundations and the most important structural properties of democracies: the principles of representation and majoritarian rule. The second part, "The performance of democracies?", is devoted to the achievements and shortcomings of democratic systems in terms of conflict management, welfare maximization and international peace. The last section, "Challenges to democracy", deals with the most important contemporary problems of democracy such as globalization, societal fragmentation and the issue of universalism.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- ISS students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;
                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Marco Verweij</span>&#13;

                                                                        Soc.Mov.Pol.Part.&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Soc.Mov.Pol.Part." /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Research Paper (40%)<br />Presentation (30%)<br />Quizz(es) (20%)<br />Active Participation (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The readings for this course may be a bit on the heavy side. However, there is neither a mid-term nor a final exam. Moreover, I have done my utmost to pick the most readable and interesting publications. You will be required to finish all the required readings in advance, and prepare at least one question for class discussion every week. (Please note: the background readings are recommended only). In order to help you get motivated (and much in line with the famous words once uttered by erstwhile social movement-leader Vladimir Lenin: trust is good, but control is better), I will test your knowledge of the literature with a brief, written quiz every week. This is a seminar, and class participation will be much appreciated (and likewise rewarded). In addition to the weekly quizzes and class participation, you will be graded on the basis of a class presentation and a research paper, for which I will help you prepare.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        "This course introduces students to the history, theory and current impact of social movements. It explores the claims, actions, forms, causes and consequences of the main social movements during the last few centuries. It critically discusses past and current theories of social movements, including Relative Deprivation Theory, Resource Mobilization Theory and Frame Analysis. As it is hard to fully comprehend social movements without understanding their main rivals and allies in the political arena (such as political parties, interest groups and bureaucracies), the seminar also focuses on the rationales and ways of organising of these other social forces. During the last four weeks, the roles of social movements and their opponents are analysed in a variety of the major issues of today, including climate change, globalization and anti-poverty efforts, and Islamic fundamentalism."<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Integrated Social Sciences (ISS).<br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This introductory lecture looks at basic patterns of social relations and analyzes the conditions of their stability, reproduction and change. In particular, it investigates social inequalities based on class, race and gender, deals with the issues of demographic transition, collective action and social conflict, and analyzes central social institutions such as the family, the labor market, the educational system and religion.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
