                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;
                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Klaus Schömann</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Civ.Netw./Soc.Cap.&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Civ.Netw./Soc.Cap." /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
                                                <input type="hidden" name="sws" value="3" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | 30&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Various written assignments (50%)<br />Active Participation (25%)<br />Presentations (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar has mandatory attendance. Beyond that students will be graded based on <br />participation (25%), presentations (25%), and various written assignment (position papers and a written exam, 50%). This is a seminar, which means that attendance AND participation is important and that students are expected to prepare for each meeting. Each student will do a number of presentations (the exact number to be determined when the number of participants is known). In the presentations, you will be graded based on academic content, presentation skill, and contribution to the seminar discussions.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The market, the state, and the other macro-institutions discussed in modules I and II are embedded in social structures at the micro-level. This seminar examines the importance of personal trust, relational networks, and social capital for the functioning of the larger structures of society. It explains how apparently 'good' structures can fail in the absence of adequate social support, and how, on the basis of civic networks and social capital, citizens can work around, and change apparently 'bad' structures.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The concept of social capital is one of the key concepts in the social sciences. The concepts popularity stems from its wide-ranging application to social, economic and political problems in modern and developing societies. However, the scholarly debate on social capital reveals multifaceted literatures that span individual and collective approaches including some attempts to bridge the two. Depending on the realm of application the concept and theory of social capital has various meanings. Social and civic networks, as well as network architecture and dynamics, are central elements in social capital theory. We shall discuss applications of these concepts and their relevance for real world phenomena. <br />This seminar aims at making students familiar with 1) the conceptual and theoretical foundation of social capital, including classical origins 2) the measurement of social capital, 3) the sources of social capital, 4) and the outcomes of social capital at individual and collective levels. The presentation of social capital in this course is firmly grounded in a social networks and civil society approach.  In the seminar we shall discuss the different understandings of social capital and how they relate and differ. Additionally, we will bridge to fundamental questions of cooperation, reciprocity, trust, participation, status attainment, mobilization, and community. <br /><br />This class makes use of Turnitin for all written submissions (position papers and written exam). Please make sure you have an account (www.turnitin.com) and that you are accustomed to the system. <br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="60" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Inside Apple Paper (30%, Mandatory)<br />Research Journal Report (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory and participation is monitored. The instructor can award a bonus or malus to the final grade reflecting the student's attendance and participation.<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Organizing is a key management activity and organizations are both the context and the object of managerial work. This course introduces students to fundamental ideas on why organizations exist, how people behave in organizations, how organizations can be designed and changed strategically, and how they evolve in their environments. Managers also need to build and maintain inter-organizational relationships in projects, alliances, networks, supply chains and partnerships with various other organizations and in increasingly international contexts. The course covers classical principles of the division and integration of labor within and across firms. It also fosters a critical perspective on organizing as an ongoing creative, collective and contested practice that entails limitations for managerial control. Through project work, students learn what it means to be part of, and responsible for, contemporary organizations.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and in Module III "Management of Supply Chains and Networks" in the BSc program International Logistics. <br /><br />- GEM students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4) or spring 3 (semester 6). <br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br />The course is divided into Group A and Group B. The groups are taught together on Tuesdays (interactive lecture) and seperately on Thursdays (seminar/lab).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Physical movements of goods leave a financial trail. Accounting is the art of capturing this trail and transforming it into meaningful information for management and other stakeholders. This course provides an introduction to accounting principles. It focuses on measuring the financial position and performance of a firm, on reporting cash flows and on analyzing financial statements. It consists of modules on strategic and operative planning as well as on controlling (target setting, feed-back and feed-forward control, balanced scorecard). Cost allocation, full costing and cost-volume-profit analysis are the focus of managerial accounting.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and in Module I: Financial Management and Controlling in the BSc program International Logistics. <br /><br />- GEM students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br /><br />This course was not offered in spring 2011, therefore IL students in their final semester, may also need to take this course now in spring 2012. <br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Grade&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Corporate Finance is crucial to the growth of all firms. This is even more so in a global environment that is characterized by liquidity shortages and turmoil in capital markets.<br />This course will provide students with the basics of corporate finance. It will introduce to the analytical tools and the necessary techniques for the financial management of a firm. Students will discuss these techniques in various contexts: the modern theories of corporate finance, corporate governance, value and capital budgeting, risk and return, capital structure and dividend policy, finance decisions as well as long term and short term financial planning.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and in Module I: Financial Management and Controlling in the BSc Program International Logistics. <br /><br />- GEM students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="90" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This seminar continues the analysis of the market. It asks why in market economies, not all economic transactions take place within the market. Why are some transactions moved outside of the market and coordinated hierarchically within business firms? The seminar examines both the internal organization and management of business firms and their external behavior. The topics covered include the economics of transaction costs, agency theory, elementary game theory, competitive advantage, strategy formation, and strategic pricing.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who successfully complete this course will not receive credits towards the 180 ECTS-credits required for their BA degree from the course Fundamentals of International Business (032 201). These courses are mutually exclusive due to comparable content.<br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB) and International Logistics (IL).<br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br />- IL students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        With the knowledge of what Logistics in general includes and after an introduction to law, both in the past terms, this course will deal with the legal aspects of transportation, for-warding and logistics. After an outline of several aspects of international and national trade law which includes the formation of contracts, incorporation of general conditions in general and the law of sales contracts, we will focus on national law of transportation, lo-gistics and freight forwarding. Thereafter the international conventions for the carriage of goods by sea, by air and by land including multimodal carriage will be subject of the course. Since logistics is a manifold area we will have to include several aspects like law of warehousing and the assembling of products. <br /><br />At last, we will focus on the law of other contracts which are necessarily connected with the transport/logistics, e. g. insurance, agency, construction and long term contracts, product liability. <br /><br />The course will include an outline of the international private law (conflicts of law), jurisdiction, litigation and arbitration.<br /><br />Of course the student should be aware that the legal entities acting in the logistic business have different legal structures. Therefore, an outlook to the company law with connected aspects will be given. <br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        A reader has been prepared for this course. Participation in the course will necessitate the close use of the reader.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                              - | 30&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Marketing covers a set of diverse practices that connect firms to their relevant markets. This course introduces the principal marketing decision-making areas known as the four Ps: product, price, promotion and place. Actual decisions on these parameters depend on how firms communicate with, and learn from, their customers who may be private consumers (B2C) or other firms (B2B) buying goods as well as services. Students learn that marketing strategies are also shaped by how firms marketing is integrated with other business functions, by the behaviors of competitors and partner firms, and by the values, needs, and standards in the firms environment. Marketing plays a key role in firms internationalization strategies and, building on many practical examples, the course familiarizes students with issues around foreign market entry, globalization and localization of marketing policies, and coordination within multinationals.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in Global Economics and Management (GEM) and for the IL module "Marketing and Strategies". <br /><br />This course will be offered for GEM students according to their mandatory table in their fall 2 (semester 3) semester.<br /><br />In Spring 2012  IL students (in particular those in the 3rd or 2nd year) will be given priority at registration . If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly. <br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;

                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Michael Hülsmann</span>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        StratInnMan&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="StratInnMan" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Oral Exam (75%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation (25%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course intends to offer the students opportunities to acquire the necessary knowledge, to develop a comprehensive understanding, and to leverage the competencies, which are needed for a strategic innovation management in logistics. Hence, the course aims for the integration of innovations and strategies into the logistics management.Therefore, the course combines a service marketing perspective with the innovation management process. This includes the identification and analysis of problems of logistics service products and processes, the generation and collection of ideas for solving the given problems, the strategic evaluation of technology-based alternatives, the approaches for the implementation of a selected technology in products and processes,the marketing of innovations and their contribution to the competitive advantage of a company (i.e. a logistics service provider). Additionally, drivers of innovations and their diffusion process will be discussed. On the background of innovations and their management the strategic options of quality leadership vs. cost leadership will be outlined for the strategic purposes of logistics service companies. Therefore, a combination of lectures, case studies, and textbook analyses (self-study) set up the didactical framework.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Midterm Exam (30%)<br />Presentation (30%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Mass media and communication networks permeate almost all aspects of contemporary societies. This lecture provides an overview of the more traditional forms of one-to-many communication by mass media and the more recent forms of one-to-one and many-to-many communication facilitated by new technologies, such as the internet. It introduces students to key issues and concepts in communication science, and reviews 'classic' studies in order to illustrate the co-evolution of media systems and media theory.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB).<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2)<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="81" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Poster (40%)<br />Presentation (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The production, distribution, presentation, and use of media is an important determinant of the size, density, development, innovative energy and adaptability of human groups, societies and cultural zones. Although modern media transcend national borders, distinct national and regional media cultures remain. This seminar compares media cultures across the major regions of the world: Europe, the United States, Latin America, Africa, and the Asian Pacific. It analyzes the structural setting of mass communication systems, and examines their cultural forms and content.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB) , and Global Economics and Management.<br /><br />Group A: GEM and IPH students preferred in registration<br />Group B: IRB and ISS students preferred in registration<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />As this course could not be offered in spring 2011 it is also mandatory in spring 2012 for 3rd year ISS, IRB and GEM students.<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

Müller";}}s:19:"970142 Human Rights";a:3:{s:4:"link";s:188:"https://campusnet.jacobs-university.de/scripts/mgrqispi.dll?APPNAME=CampusNet&PRGNAME=COURSEDETAILS&ARGUMENTS=-N000000000000001,-N000114,-N0,-N345284056518391,-N345284056557392,-N0,-N0,-N0";s:11:"information";a:2:{s:11:"description";s:4145:"<table class="tb" courseid="345284056557392"><caption>Course offering details</caption>&#13;
                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;

                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Dr. Georg Ress</span>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Human Rights&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Human Rights" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
                                                <input type="hidden" name="sws" value="3" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Midterm Exam (40%)<br />Protocol (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Human Rights have gained a particular importance in the 20th century as part of international public law. They have resulted in the acceptance of the individual as a subject of International Law, a position traditionally enjoyed by only the state. The seminar will deal with the role of Human Rights as part of General International Law and in particular of Humanitarian Law (Law of War) and the regulation of Human Rights in the United Nations 'Covenant on Civil and Political Rights' and the UN 'Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights'. The practice of the UN committee will be addressed as well as the practice of different regional bodies of protection of Human Rights, as the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, the African Court and in particular the European Court of Human Rights. The case law of the European Court of Human Rights is of particular interest for the development of the nature, structure and content of Human Rights not only in Europe, and one of the interesting chapters will be how far this jurisprudence has found its reception in various national legal orders. The lecture will focus around the question what it means that central values and interests have found its codification in the development of Human Rights. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course includes a  3-day excursion to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France. Time tbd.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%, Mandatory)<br />Midterm Exam (40%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (5%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance (5%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course provides a broad overview of European history between the French Revolution and the end of the 20th century. As many topics in modern European history are addressed more extensively in more specific courses in modules II to IV, and since some of this history is familiar to most students from their high school history courses, the objective of this lecture is an introduction to a historical understanding and interpretation of major processes in those two centuries, and the emphasis therefore is rather on historical concepts and interpretations than on summarizing facts and events. As part of the World Regions and Civilizations module, the course will also try to sensitize students to the particular identity of a common European history, as opposed to the recent history of other world regions. On the other hand, students will learn about the diversity of European cultures and the most important "sub-regions" of modern European history. Topics include the transformation of Ancien Régimes and revolutionary change; the emergence of industrial societies and economies; the formation of nation-states and empire-building, modern political ideologies such as liberalism, nationalism, or socialism; war, dictatorship and the European dimensions of the Holocaust; post-war prosperity and environmental changes.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        <tr><td class="tbdata" colspan="3">&#13;
                        <!-- LIST OF COURSE PROPS -->&#13;

                                                                        Mod-Econ-Hist&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Mod-Econ-Hist" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                                                                          5.00&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Participation, attendance, quizzes (50%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation, essay, paper (50%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The major economic transformation of the world that started in 18th-century England constitutes the core concern of this lecture. Since the field of modern economic history has witnessed a major transformation, with a significant expansion of both its subject area and its theoretical foundations, the classical process of the Industrial Revolution in technology and production will form an important starting point, but will not any more exclusively define this field. Attention will also be given to the preconditions of industrial growth in the agricultural and commercial economy of early-modern Europe. The history of economic processes has begun to include not just production, but also trade and consumption, as modern societies are increasingly defined as "consumer societies". In addition, the "cultural turn" has had its impact also on economic history, leading to a new emphasis on economic action, economic ideology, and the cultural implications of economic behavior. The lecture provides an overview over both classical and new topics in modern economic history, from early-modern beginnings to postwar economies after 1945 and issues of economic "globalization", and at the same time introduces students to different ways of conceptualizing past economies. The chief interest lies on Western economies, but their interrelations with local and dependent economies on the fringes of the Western world are also considered.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this semester the course focuses on the U.S. experience with economic growth and development. Starting with the first European settlements and the Colonial Era we will follow the ascendance of the U.S. from an agrarian economy to the worlds leading economic power.<br /><br />A mandatory introductory class will take place on Friday, February 3, when presentation topics will be introduced and distributed. At this session students must sign up for a presentation; no-shows and latecomers will not be considered. On February 10, students will present a first draft of an outline and an annotated bibliography for their research paper.<br /><br />Other important elements of this class are an essay and a research paper. Regular attendance is required and knowledge of the reading assignments will be reviewed through quizzes.<br /><br />This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: International Politics and History (IPH), and Integrated Cultural Studies (ICS)<br /><br />- IPH students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- ICS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Int.Rel.20th.Cent.&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Int.Rel.20th.Cent." /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="31" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Presentation and Handout (35%)<br />Active Participation (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance<br />Attendance is mandatory. You can be absent without an official excuse for two out of thirteen weeks. Any further absence without official excuse will lead to a downgrading of your overall grade by 0.33 per weekly absence.<br /><br />Grading Information: <br /> Active participation in class: a) oral contribution in discussions on texts of the seminar reader, and b) two short essays: one take-home essay, one in class-essay, together : 25%*<br /> Presentation and Handout: 35%<br /> Finals: 40%<br /><br />*there are three possible assessments regarding the oral participation: active participation (25%), moderate participation (16%), passive (no) participation (0%)<br /><br />Further grading information<br /> - 25% Active Participation : Attendance alone will not count significantly towards your participation grade.  Please take responsibility not only for doing the assigned readings each week but also for thinking carefully about those readings. What are the authors perspectives, and what are the main terms and arguments they are trying to convey? What do you find puzzling or surprising or disturbing about the readings? Be prepared to contribute your insights each week.<br />Two short essays (3-4 pages): You will be asked to briefly summarize the main aspects of the readings and comment critically on them.<br /><br /> - 35%  Presentation and Handout: The group presentation should be ca. 25 minutes long. The presentation will be followed by a discussion. A handout (about 2 pages) should list the major issues of the presentation, including the research question, your conclusions and proposals for discussion.<br /><br /> -  40%:  Finals (90 Minutes): About ten short knowledge questions,  related to the readings and the slides; answer one essay question (chosen out of two given essay questions).<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The seminar builds on the previous lecture on nineteenth century international relations. It provides an opportunity for a more detailed study of international relations in a broad sense, i.e. including politics and transnational activities. The analysis of major conflicts and developments from the First World War to the end of the Cold War provides students with a critical understanding of the making of today's world. Through the close reading of available documents and the engagement with scholarly debates, the structure of international relations, its institutions and underlying forces, as well as major events which shaped politicians' behavior gain life. The course focuses on issues like the origins of wars, peace-making, collective security, crisis management, economic dependency and cultural diplomacy. It highlights features particular to the twentieth century; the potential of mass destruction and its realization, the role of ideologies, the expansion of international organizations, economic relations and an increasing but uneven linkage between societies all over the world. The tension between fragmentation and globalization, which we still see today, is thus explained in historical terms.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Democ.Gov.&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="35" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Research Paper (50%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance (10%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Democracy is both a normative ideal and an empirical type of political governance. This seminar explores both dimensions. It is divided into three parts. The first part, "What is democracy?", deals with conceptual foundations and the most important structural properties of democracies: the principles of representation and majoritarian rule. The second part, "The performance of democracies?", is devoted to the achievements and shortcomings of democratic systems in terms of conflict management, welfare maximization and international peace. The last section, "Challenges to democracy", deals with the most important contemporary problems of democracy such as globalization, societal fragmentation and the issue of universalism.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), and International Politics and History (IPH).<br />- ISS students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br />- IPH students take this course in spring 3 (semester 6).<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="81" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Poster (40%)<br />Presentation (40%)<br />Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The production, distribution, presentation, and use of media is an important determinant of the size, density, development, innovative energy and adaptability of human groups, societies and cultural zones. Although modern media transcend national borders, distinct national and regional media cultures remain. This seminar compares media cultures across the major regions of the world: Europe, the United States, Latin America, Africa, and the Asian Pacific. It analyzes the structural setting of mass communication systems, and examines their cultural forms and content.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the following BA programs: Integrated Social Sciences (ISS), Intercultural Relations and Behavior (IRB) , and Global Economics and Management.<br /><br />Group A: GEM and IPH students preferred in registration<br />Group B: IRB and ISS students preferred in registration<br /><br />- ISS students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- IRB students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4)<br />- GEM students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4).<br /><br />As this course could not be offered in spring 2011 it is also mandatory in spring 2012 for 3rd year ISS, IRB and GEM students.<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        970202&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                              - | 39&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="39" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Essay 1 (25%, Mandatory)<br />Essay 2 (25%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Group Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Quizzes (10%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course introduces the student to the theory and practice of public management and public policy analysis. On the one hand, the course will provide the student with an overview of what public management is today, how it has changed in the past 30 or so years and where it is going. Not only will the course expose students to contemporary thinking in public management, by looking at the way public managers over the world deal with today's policy challanges, the course will also allow students to apply this knowledge to real cases. On the other hand, the course exposes students to the conceptual and methodological tool-box of contemporary policy analysis and, by drawing on real-life examples from a variety of policy domains, shows students how academic and professional policy analysts bring this tool-box to bear on issues of public management and public policy. Additionally, the course will show how different socio-cultural, political or disciplinary frames of references shape policy analysis and how policy analysts can use these frames to sharpen their understanding of the way public institutions are managed.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This is a mandatory course for the BA program in International Politics and History (IPH) and for BSc program Integrated Environmental Studies (IES) - "Energy Policy and Technology Specialization" <br />- IPH students take this course in spring 1 (semester 2).<br />- IES students take this course in spring 2 (semester 4). <br /><br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to the above mentioned cohort(s) of students. If places are still vacant students will be allocated randomly.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Paper (35%)<br />Midterm Exam (30%)<br />Active Participation incl. presentation and attendance (25%)<br />Academic Report (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course investigates the historical evolution of important ideologies such as liberalism, nationalism, communism and fascism. It discusses their commonalities, differences, clashes and reactions to each other. Focusing on Europe and China as prime examples, we will analyze how some political currents turned into powerful global movements. After all, political ideals were not just abstract theories but also movements transforming entire states and societies.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="75" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (50%)<br />Midterm Exam (50%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course extends the discussion of quantitative methods beyond the introductory level. It reviews some exemplary pieces of quantitative research in the social sciences in order to explain basic statistical concepts and examine their potential and limitations. The topics covered include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, regression and correlation, and analysis of variance. The course is equally divided between lecture and lab sessions. During the lab sessions, the tools and concepts discussed during the lecture sessions are applied to real life data sets. The course also serves as a basic training in the statistics software SPSS.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who successfully complete this course will not receive credits towards the 180 ECTS-credits required for their BA degree from the course Statistical Concepts and Data Analysis (990 121). These courses are mutually exclusive due to comparable content.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Home Work (40%)<br />Exam (30%)<br />Quizz(es) (30%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        There will be eight homework assignments distributed throughout the semester. Each will be worth the same amount. Only the best five assignments will be counted.<br />There will be two quizzes: one given in the first half of March, the other one towards the end of the semester.<br />Students will have the opportunity to gain bonus points by participating in psychology experiments. For each 30 minutes of participation, students will gain one point which adds 0.5 percentage points to the final grade. A maximum of ten bonus points can be awarded per student.<br />Final grades are determined by the TOTAL of all points earned during the term  NOT by any average of the individual letter grades on separate parts  by using the Jacobs University percentage grading scheme. This means that you have to achieve 45% or more to pass the course and 95% or more to get a 1.00.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course aims to provide an introduction to fundamental statistical concepts and tools for data analysis. It is intended as a one-semester course that combines selected topics from both the mandatory statistical methods courses for SHSS students (Statistical Methods I: Exploring Relationships and Comparing Groups and Statistical Methods II: Classification, Modelling and Prediction) to offer the more relevant topics for logistics and SES major students. The course will focus on the understanding of statistical concepts and the application of statistical techniques. While some formulae might be used, no stringent mathematical derivation will be provided. The general objective is to become an intelligent user of the various univariate and multivariate statistical techniques and to acquire the knowledge for deciding which procedure is most suitable for the given business situation. We will discuss the theoretical aspects of the statistical methods, discuss the assumptions for their use, reflect on their limitations and the controversies they create. In practical sessions we will learn how to run the particular procedures using SPSS and/or R, how to interpret the computer output and how to skillfully communicate the results of statistical analyses. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Students who successfully complete this course will not receive credits towards the 180 ECTS-credits required for their BA degree from the courses "Statistical Methods I (course-no.: 990102)" and "Statistical Methods II (course-no.: 990201)".<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="60" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Research paper (25%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance (15%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation of a Study (15%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation of an Outline (15%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation of an Activity (10%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation of Progress Report (10%, Mandatory)<br />Readings-check (10%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Qualitative research is concerned with meaning  for instance, the meaning that events have for people, or the meaning of written texts or works of art. By applying qualitative methods, researchers seek to obtain an in-depth understanding of these meanings. <br /><br />The course examines the methodological foundations of qualitative research, introduces purposive sampling strategies that are especially suitable for an in-depth discovery of meaning, discusses how researchers from the humanities and social sciences acquire their data (for instance through interviews, focus groups, or observation), and reviews methods for the analysis of qualitative data (such as: various types of coding, content analysis, discourse analysis, visual analysis). Special emphasis is placed on examining the quality of qualitative research, including the extent to which the traditional criteria of objectivity, reliability, and validity can be applied. <br /><br />The course is held in part as a seminar and in part as a lab where students apply the methods to data from their own fields of study. During the lab sessions, students are required to participate in and report on activities involving the application and trying out of selected methods. Also, students will develop, carry out, and report on small group research projects, fostering the integration of methodological knowledge about methods and designs with practical expertise in applying these methods. Lab sessions are run with small groups to ensure optimal supervision of research projects. <br /><br />The course will be held in two sessions of 75 minutes each. The Thursday session will consist of an overview, the subsequent Wednesday session of a lab where students will have the opportunity to try out and discuss the methods. <br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Econometrics&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Econometrics" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course focuses on the analysis of secondary data in the business world. Thus, one focus of the course consists of quantitative methods used in economy and business. We will expand on the knowledge acquired in the statistics class and intensify discussion of multiple regression analysis, in particualr with an emphasis on longitudinal/time dependent data. The second focus of the course is on the analysis of large data sets that are created during the regular business process, such as billing data, customer information, etc.; data, that is more and more analysed by computer-intensive methods to find structure and patterns.<br />The general objective is to become familiar with classic and contemporary methods that are used in econometric and business analyses and to become a critical reader of case studies in this field. We will take a practical approach to learn how to run the particular procedures in state of the art software. To foster the practical approach homeworks and projects will be assigned. By the end of this course, students will know the rules for being competent practitioners of econometrics. This involves:<br />Understanding how data should be organized for undertaking econometric modeling and the steps required for preparing data for analysis; Recognizing what technique to select from the econometric toolkit given the pattern of values in the data; Being able to interpret results with respect to both their statistical and economic/social significance; Be able to cast a skeptical eye on econometric results in the literature; Have fun working with social science data<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Presentation (37%)<br />Midterm Exam (33%)<br />Home Work 1 (10%)<br />Home Work 2 (10%)<br />Home Work 3 (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course will not encompass a final exam; there will just be a late midterm exam. Other grading componants are 3 homework tasks interspersed across the semester in a way compatible with the progress of the course, and a presentation. After spring break students will have to present (in a group of a size yet to be determined) their own analyses to fellow course attendees.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course focuses on the analysis of secondary data on the disciplinary borders of psychology, sociology, and political science. It will introduce the participants to the use of structural equation modeling on data that have been gathered in research conducted in these fields. A thorough introduction into the use of the program package AMOS (special module of SPSS) will be given in a hands-on practical way. The software as well as the data to be worked on will be provided, but interested students can also work on own data.<br />We will engage in confirmatory factor analyses and contrast them with exploratory factor analysis as taught in the Statistics II lecture. We will furthermore conduct model tests of regression model with latent and manifest endogenous and exogenous variables, and will in this context deal with problems like 'correlated error.' A further problem approached in the course will be possibilities to secure cross-cultural equivalence of scales, and, finally, the analysis of panel data within the framework of structural equation<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course will be conducted in a way that follows the lecture + lab model. In Session 1 of every week the instructor will offer information of a new segment of the use of structural equation modelling, while in Session 2 the practical steps to adequately perform the analyses portrayed in the lecture will be trained.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Prof. Dr. Otthein Herzog; Prof. Dr. Dr. Peter Ludes</span>&#13;
                                </p>&#13;
                                                                                                        <b>Type:</b>&#13;
                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Graduate Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Graduate Seminar" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          7.50&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  7.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />moving poster (40%)<br />moving poster (40%)<br />visual analysis (10%)<br />visual analysis (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Visualization is one of the most prominent features in international communication. This module focuses on the structures, functions as well as on the formats and contents of visual communication.<br />Visual and textual communication complement each other. But visual communication transcends national borders more easily since images are - at least on the level of human perception - not restricted by language barriers. Textual communication also follows a different communication pattern than visual communication. While mass media texts are usually read and interpreted according to an underlying argumentative structure, the logic of mass media images is rather based on association. As a consequence the global transfer of visual mass media products appears to be easy, because no translation of the image seems to be necessary. But images from other cultures can violate cultural and religious traditions and thus create social and political tension. Moreover, visual content is interpreted in different ways around the world. The contextualization of visual communication also in terms of its role in mixed sign systems, especially in audio-visual communication is thus an important aspect of this module. Students learn how the social, political and cultural environments in which visual media are perceived are crucial for comprehending the structures, functions and messages of international visual communication. The visual material used may vary from year to year. <br />The Issues Course deepens these insights by focusing on concrete case studies.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Literary Theory&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Literary Theory" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
                                                <input type="hidden" name="sws" value="3" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          7.50&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  7.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Essay (30%, Mandatory)<br />Report (30%, Mandatory)<br />Active Participation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course introduces theories of text and textuality on the basis that literature constitutes a multitude of particular discursive practices. Intertextuality and the concept of interculturality provide new perspectives on text that demand the application and - simultaneously - reorientation of literary and cultural theory. The course conveys fundamental insights into epistemological paradigms in the history of literary theory, focusing on text and context, the role of author and reader, the problems and limits of mimetic representation, and cultural and intercultural correspondences of literature.<br />Selections from "canonical" texts on literary theory and major positions on text and textuality, from Antiquity to contemporary literary theory, form the textual basis for presentations and classroom discussions on the poetics and grammar of literary and non-literary texts in an intercultural context. How critical theory can be applied to literary, media, and intercultural phenomena, how ¿text¿ can be reconceptualized and how literary theory provides descriptive models for cultural practices that go beyond national definitions of literary texts constitutes one of the major aims of this seminar.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Literature and the Canon  Problems and Possibilities<br /><br />This graduate course on literature and problems/possibilities of the canon will focus on an extensive body of books and the theory associated with canonicity. Harold Bloom famously stated that the canon, once we view it as the relation of an individual reader and writer to what has been preserved out of what has been written, and forget the canon as a list of books for required study, will be seen as identical with the literary Art of Memory. This comment will be one of the starting points for in-depth discussions of texts written and published in English ranging from winners of the Man-Booker Prize to Nobel Prize winning authors. And of course we will be studying books that did not make it onto the lists  for political, aesthetic, or economic reasons. Special attention will also be devoted to the presence/recognition of postcolonial writers in the contexts of these two prizes. <br /><br />This class will be taught by Dr. Maaheen Ahmed and Prof. Thomas Rommel.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Research Paper (40%, Mandatory)<br />Attendance, class participation and reading assignments (20%, Mandatory)<br />Poster Presentation (20%, Mandatory)<br />Presentation and Discussion of a Selected Topic (20%, Mandatory)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Visual and material manifestations of intercultural exchange have been a central focus of art history¿s project. The course provides insights into methodological approaches that theorize intercultural transfers and aesthetic appropriations in the field of visual art. It will combine the discussion of key concepts and major readings from art history, cultural and visual theory and post-colonial critique with empirical studies in the history of collecting and colonialism, including models of artistic exchange, the role of international exhibitions, Biennials, the art market and contemporary discourses in art<br />criticism, that address the fact that Non-Western art has virtually been ignored by traditional art history and critically maintain the quest for post-colonial self-reflections of the discipline.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This graduate course on literature and problems/possibilities of the canon will focus on an extensive body of books and the theory associated with canonicity. Harold Bloom famously stated that the canon, once we view it as the relation of an individual reader and writer to what has been preserved out of what has been written, and forget the canon as a list of books for required study, will be seen as identical with the literary Art of Memory. This comment will be one of the starting points for in-depth discussions of texts written and published in English ranging from winners of the Man-Booker prize to Nobel prize winning authors. And of course we will be studying books that did not make it onto the lists  for political, aesthetic, or economic reasons. Special attention will also be devoted to the presence/ recognition of postcolonial writers in the contexts of these two prizes. <br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This class will be taught by Dr. Maaheen Ahmed and Prof. Thomas Rommel, and Intercultural Humanities students in their final semester may register for this course. Details about the structure and organization of "Literature and the Canon" will be discussed in the first session.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />moving poster (40%)<br />moving poster (40%)<br />visual analysis (10%)<br />visual analysis (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Visualization is one of the most prominent features in international communication. This module focuses on the structures, functions as well as on the formats and contents of visual communication.<br />Visual and textual communication complement each other. But visual communication transcends national borders more easily since images are - at least on the level of human perception - not restricted by language barriers. Textual communication also follows a different communication pattern than visual communication. While mass media texts are usually read and interpreted according to an underlying argumentative structure, the logic of mass media images is rather based on association. As a consequence the global transfer of visual mass media products appears to be easy, because no translation of the image seems to be necessary. But images from other cultures can violate cultural and religious traditions and thus create social and political tension. Moreover, visual content is interpreted in different ways around the world. The contextualization of visual communication also in terms of its role in mixed sign systems, especially in audio-visual communication is thus an important aspect of this module. Students learn how the social, political and cultural environments in which visual media are perceived are crucial for comprehending the structures, functions and messages of international visual communication. The visual material used may vary from year to year. <br />The Issues Course deepens these insights by focusing on concrete case studies.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course deals with the most important competing theories, paradigms and metatheoretical orientations in research on international relations, global governance, and globalization, and places them within the context of general social theory. They are thus examined with reference to historical precursors, comparable contemporary phenomena from other social science fields, and general social theory. Realism, institutionalism, constructivism, world systems theory and world society theory all refer back to well-known basic concepts, constructs, principles, or assumptions, and this course will show that a contextualization generates theoretical resources that can be used both to critically analyze the different paradigms and to compare them. This seminar builds on the previous seminar in this module area (Normative Theories of International Order) and on the introduction to the basic elements of theory offered in the first semester course "Theories of Action and Institutions".<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will be offered from 22.03. - 28.06.2012 and will take place at Uni Bremen.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;
                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        Grad(IR): Transform.&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Grad(IR): Transform." /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><br /><br /><b>Hours per week: </b>&#13;
                                                                        3&#13;
