                                                                          7.50&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  7.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The state is widely considered to be the most important actor in international governance and at the same time a key concept in the social sciences. In recent years it has been argued that profound transformations are taking place which challenge the very foundations of the externally and internally sovereign modern state. The main tendencies of these transformations are the emergence of increasingly autonomous public or private institutions at the international level and the emergence of semi-autonomous functional subsystems and powerful private actors at the domestic level. Governance thus takes place in a complex multi-level system with a variety of public and private actors. The course analyzes these developments, and their consequence for modern governance, both theoretically and by looking in more detail at concrete examples.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will be offered from 12.03. - 04.06.2012 and will take place at Uni Bremen.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is about the interaction of international economic developments, on the one hand, and international and domestic politics on the other. It examines both theoretical perspectives on, and historical experience with, cross-border movements of trade, money, capital, and people. It looks at sources and modes of regulation and at effects on politics within and between nations. Special emphasis will be placed on a comparison between present day globalisation and the international political economy of the Pre-World War I, Interwar and Post-War periods.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will run from 27.03.-19.06.2012<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        Students will focus on historical processes that significantly marked the 19th century and ultimately gave the 20th century the name ¿age of the extremes¿, namely, dictatorships, war, and violence.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In spite of an ongoing process of secularization some religions are spreading rapidly e.g. Protestantism and Islam. In these cases modernization did not undermine the credibility of religions; in contrast it became itself the seedbed for the formation of new kinds of religiosity as e.g. Pentecostalism, Apocalypticism and Esotericism. New kinds of religious communality arose. Independent of existing hierarchies laymen established voluntary religious associations, that turned out to be a rich matrix for new religious practices and an eminent source for social capital.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

Kippenberg";}}s:53:"600482 Graduate Seminar (MGH): Modern Russian History";a:3:{s:4:"link";s:188:"https://campusnet.jacobs-university.de/scripts/mgrqispi.dll?APPNAME=CampusNet&PRGNAME=COURSEDETAILS&ARGUMENTS=-N000000000000001,-N000114,-N0,-N344384487895808,-N344384487817809,-N0,-N0,-N0";s:11:"information";a:2:{s:11:"description";s:3669:"<table class="tb" courseid="344384487817809"><caption>Course offering details</caption>&#13;

                                                        <p>&#13;
                                        <b>Instructors: </b><span id="dozenten">Dr. Maike Lehmann</span>&#13;

                                        Seminar&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  4" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;

                                                                        600482&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="600482" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  7.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        During the 20th century, the political, cultural, and social conditions in Russia and Eastern Europe underwent dramatic changes. The First World War, the Second World War, and the Cold War defined the region for decades. From 1917 to 1991 Russia stood as a symbol of the Soviet system, which promised a different social and political alternative to Capitalism. It symbolized the division of the world in ¿East¿ and ¿West¿. The revolutions of 1989 in Eastern Europe gave way to a new era in contemporary history. The history of the Eastern European region during the 20th century is characterized by processes of nation building, controversies surrounding imperial structures, wars, policies of extermination, the relocation of populations as well as by boosts of modernization, the superimposition of systems and the struggle for independent identities. On the one hand, the Soviet Union reached geographically deep into Asia through Siberia and the Central Asian states. On the other hand, the definition of Eastern Europe and its boundary to Central Europe are until today fluid and controversial. The study of this region gives an insight into its modern history by focusing on case studies and the experiences of entire nations, social groups and individuals. The relevant 19th century history of the region will also be covered.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Home Work (30%)<br />Presentation (30%)<br />Project (30%)<br />Active Participation (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course aims to provide an overview and understanding of some of the more commonly used and applied statistical techniques. It will cover methods for both continuous data as well as categorical data. The standard setting will be the supervised learning situation in which there is one target variable, the behavior of which is to be predicted by some other variables. We will briefly revise the essentials of confirmatory statistics, including hypothesis testing, significance and power, as well as the ideas behind data reduction, prediction and explanation.<br />The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or algebra. The focus will be on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques.<br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course will be offered from 14.03. - 13.06.2012<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        <p>        <b>Course Name Abbreviation: </b>&#13;
                                                                        USCMegacities II&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="USCMegacities II" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;
                                                                          2.50&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  2.50" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Urbanization and the resulting evolution of megacities are a worldwide phenomenon. Megacities face certain challenges that differ from those of smaller cities: examples are freshwater, food and energy supply, sewage and waste disposal, disaster control and prevention, governance, traffic and health care, and social divides, just to name a few. This course is not specifically directed towards students from either SHSS or SES, but is meant to act as an introduction to these complex and interdisciplinary issues. Discussion is highly encouraged and hopefully will benefit from the contributions of participants with highly different interests, expertise, cultural background and personal experience.<br /><br />This USC is different from other USCs at Jacobs University in that it is divided into two parts that extend over two semesters:<br /><br />Part I<br />In the fall semester (2.5 ECTS), Jacobs faculty and external speakers will give weekly 45 - 60 minute lectures followed by discussion. The lecture series will comprise general introductions to the different aspects of the history and development of (waterfront) mega-cities and the specific challenges they face. The lectures will touch upon the economic, social, political, natural, and infrastructural problems specific to mega-cities. Grading of this part will be based on a final exam at the end of the semester.<br />We emphasize that ATTENDANCE IS MANDATORY.<br /><br />Part II<br />In the spring semester semester (2.5 ECTS), students will work together in small working groups (maximum number of students in each group depending on the total number of registered students) in order to produce a poster on a course-related topic of their choice. It is possible to do part I of USC Megacities without doing part II, but in order to do part II, part I is a prerequisite.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                        Lecture&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="coursetyp" value="  1" /><p><b>Org-unit:</b> <span name="courseOrgUnit"></span></p>&#13;

                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="020053" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;
                              - | -&#13;
                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="-" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (30%)<br />Presentation (30%)<br />Active participation and attendance (20%)<br />Essays (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This multidisciplinary lecture provides students of different academic and practical backgrounds with a profound understanding of major aspects of development theories and modernization processes. Drawing from the experience of more than fifty years of bilateral and multilateral development assistance efforts in developing countries, including World Bank and the European Union, the course combines scientific knowledge about patterns and problems of development with practical approaches to alleviate poverty and underdevelopment in Asian, African and Latin American countries. In particular, the course covers industrialization strategies, structural adjustment policies (SAP), big push concepts, alternative policies like pro-poor growth and micro-finance devices as well as the possible contributions of education, trade, large-scale financial activity and institutions to economic growth and development.<br /><br /><br /><br />Crucial questions of the seminar program include: How to explain modernization, socio-economic progress, underdevelopment and poverty in the countries of the fragmented Third World. How to explain winners of modernization/globalization (mostly in Asia) and losers (in Sub-Saharan Africa)? Can African countries learn from Newly Industrializing Countries (NICs) in Asia? The political dimension of development strategies and theories include concepts of Good (and Bad) Governance, Curse of natural resources; Dutch disease and Rent-seeking as well as the amount of faith put in markets to achieve the must urgent development objectives.<br /><br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="30" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Contribution to the exhibition - individual contribution (30%)<br />Contribution to the exhibition - group poster presentation (25%)<br />Contribution to the exhibition - group poster presentation (25%)<br />Attendance Workshop 05.05.12 (10%)<br />Attendance Workshop 11.02.12 (10%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Contribution to the exhibition  individual contribution (30%) <br />Contribution to the exhibition  contribution to group poster presentation (25%)<br />Contribution to the exhibition  contribution to group poster presentation (25%)<br />Attendance of Workshop 11.02.12 (10%)<br />Attendance of Workshop 05.05.12 (10%)<br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        What is art, what is its purpose, and why does it matter? Drawing on art history, archaeology and anthropology and examining case studies from Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe and Oceania, this course takes a critical look at different approaches to the worlds artistic heritage and production. Further, it addresses some of the issues associated with and challenges faced by world arts today and underlines how Engineering, Computer Science and the Natural Sciences can make a major contribution to their survival.<br /><br />Part I of the course (Fall 2011) having looked at world arts from a theoretical perspective, Part II of the course (Spring 2012) will take a more practical approach and produce a small exhibition on a topic central to world arts.<br /><br />Following a one-day workshop at the beginning of the semester, when the topic and storyboard of and contributions to the exhibition will be agreed, students will work together in five working groups (drawn from different disciplines and different years) to produce their contributions  an individual contribution (500 words) and one contribution to each of the two group posters (500 words + 500 words)  to the exhibition. Each group will benefit from online support and receive one hour of personal supervision. A second one-day workshop will be held towards the end of the semester, when the exhibition will be set up, the posters presented, and the exhibition opened to the Jacobs University community. It is hoped that some students may volunteer to lead small groups of visitors around the exhibition once it has been opened.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Please note that it is a prerequisite to have successfully completed Part I of the course to register for Part II of the course. Again, discussion will be encouraged and hopefully will benefit from the contributions made by participants with different study interests, cultural backgrounds and personal experiences.<br /><br />Timetable:<br /><br />Saturday, 11 February 2012<br />One-day Workshop<br />10:00-11:15 &amp; 11:30-12:45 and 14:00-15:15 &amp; 15:30-16:45<br />Research IV Conference Room<br /><br />Wednesday, 15 February 2012<br />Feedback - Part I &amp;Advice  Part II<br />14:00-18:00 (optional - individual times tbc)<br />Research IV, Room 43<br /><br />Friday, 02 March 2012<br />Individual contributions due<br />12:00 noon<br />Research IV Team Assistants<br /><br />19-23 March 2012<br />Group Supervisions<br />dates/times tbc<br />Research IV, Room 43<br /><br />Tuesday, 20 March 2012<br />Guest Lectures (Dr. M.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="40" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        The course is intended to bridge the gap between the understanding of Life Sciences principles and its application in a Business context so as to benefit the society as a whole.<br /><br />Therefore, four distinct modules were created to fully cover the theoretical background required:<br /><br /> A first module introduces the concept of Biotechnology and the underlying technological and economic aspects; <br /> A second module introduces the vital corporate function of marketing; <br /> A third module explains the corporate function of innovation; <br /> A fourth module provides (Bio) Business with an Ethical framework. <br /><br />Furthermore, the modules mentioned before are horizontally integrated by case studies alongside the semester--- where students build up a business plan. Students will choose / define a viable business case with the assistance of the instructors. Instructors will monitor the evolution of the student teams into a well---rounded concept. <br /><br />The course will be run by four experienced Lecturers. The Instructor of record (IoR) is Prof. Fernández Lahore. <br />Each instructor will lead one the above mentioned Modules and they will synergistically cooperate during the course by attending common lectures and by supervising student groups.<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        Anti-Aging&#13;
                                        <input type="hidden" name="shortdescription" value="Anti-Aging" /></p>&#13;
                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="credits" value="  5.00" /><br /><br /><input type="hidden" name="location" value="330625958883282" /><input type="hidden" name="language" value="001" /><br /><br /><b>Min. | Max. participants:</b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="28" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Final Exam (40%)<br />Midterm Exam (40%)<br />Attendance and Active Participation (20%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        In this course we will look at several aspects of demographic change and its effects on the contemporary workplace. We will discuss the state of the art, general challenges and evidence-based approaches to mastering these challenges. A significant amount of time will be devoted to practical training and exercises to get a deeper understanding of the theoretical aspects and to enable you to apply your new knowledge to your professional work. Practical exercises and training sessions consist of small group work, individual tasks, and feedback from instructors and peers. This aims at not only gaining knowledge, but also acquire the skills to:<br />-		collect qualitative and quantitative data: designing an open-format interview and a questionnaire, observational data assessment and non-reactive information and experimental field studies.<br />-	read, analyze and generate case studies.<br />-	make use of role-play: Taking on different roles in diverse groups and settings to learn how to mediate and intervene effectively. In this session, video taping will be used.<br />-	apply Intervention Mapping: How to design and evaluate a theory and evidence based intervention to improve successful aging in the work context.<br />-	organize and facilitate reliable Quality Management: Effect, process and outcome evaluation, how to give good feedback and how to cope with unconstructive criticism.<br />-	diffuse findings, developments, strategies and policies: How to display and communicate findings and implications successfully, how to disseminate evaluation findings, how to write a top quality report and how to give a persuasive presentation.<br />-	work out effective self and time management: Train others and yourself; be a role model at work? <br />Specific emphasis will be on learning and health aspects: Why are they particularly important for an aging work force? How can employees be supported to age healthily and to successfully stay in the workforce? How does labor migration affect contemporary personnel management?<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Priority at registration will be given to 3rd years, then 2nd years and then 1st year students<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                        USC Water&#13;

                                                                                <input type="hidden" name="courselevel" value="000000000000000" /><input type="hidden" name="coursearea" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="creditingfor" value="" /><input type="hidden" name="sws" value="0" /><br /><br /><b>Credits: </b>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="-" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="60" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br /><br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Water is the basic prerequisite for life, but a scarce resource and a valuable commodity; it is of fundamental importance for the world economy and for global food supply, and hence "(civil) wars for water" are already a reality.<br /><br />In this USC we will discuss the enormous impact of water on all aspects of human life from very different perspectives: from the natural sciences, environmental sciences and engineering, from logistics and economics, from social and cultural sciences.<br /><br />The course is designed as a 2-semester course that if successful in 2012, will also be offered in 2013 and 2014. It starts with lectures and a 2/3-day excursion in Spring 2012 (2.5 ECTS credits) and continues in Fall 2012 (2.5 ECTS credits) with student projects preparing a public event at Jacobs University for World Water Day in March 2013.<br /><br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Therefore, this USC is exclusively for 1st (2nd semester) and 2nd year (4th semester) Jacobs students who will still be on campus in their 6th semester.<br />There are no prerequisites for this USC, but only those students who successfully passed "USC Water I" will be eligible to participate in "USC Water II".<br /><br />Priority at registration will be given to 2nd year students, then to 1st year students.<br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="6" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="200" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Attendance (25%, Mandatory)<br />Final Exam (25%)<br />Home Work (25%)<br />Midterm Exam (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory. Students who miss more than 3 classes without a valid excuse will fail the course.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is designed for students with very basic knowledge of German (a course A1.1 or equivalent). Throughout the course you will improve your interaction skills by speaking and listening exercises. More basic grammatical structures and sentence patterns are introduced. You will get able to read and understand simple descriptive texts and dialogues and you will learn how to write short texts such as postcards or picture descriptions. The instructor will provide you with further up-to-date contact with culture and socio-behavioral patterns in Germany. <br /><br />Students attending this course can reach language level A1 (according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages).<br /><br />Further information on the weekly schedule of your section and the material that will be covered will be provided by the instructors.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Courses with less than 6 participants will not take place. Maximum participant number is 20.<br /><br />Students are allowed to register for language courses only after attending at the placement test. <br />You can register for the language courses without a placement test<br />- if you passed your course and register for the next level<br />- if you participated at the placement test in Fall 2011<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="6" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="102" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Attendance (25%, Mandatory)<br />Final Exam (25%)<br />Home Work (25%)<br />Midterm Exam (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory. Students who miss more than 3 classes without a valid excuse will fail the course.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is designed for students with basic knowledge of German (courses of A2.1 level or equivalent). You already have a basic repertoire of words and simple phrases related to personal details and routine tasks. You will learn the highest frequency vocabulary of personal relevance and how to use it accurately.<br />You will be able to write short simple texts such as personal letters, notes, or messages. New grammar structures will be introduced. The language learning will be supported by the use of various media, which will provide the learners with up-to-date contact with culture and the socio-behavioral patterns in Germany.<br /><br />Students attending this course can reach language level A2 (according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages).<br /><br />Further information on the weekly schedule of your section and the material that will be covered will be provided by the instructor.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Courses with less than 6 participants will not take place. Maximum participant number is 20.<br /><br />Students are allowed to register for language courses only after attending at the placement test. <br />You can register for the language courses without a placement test<br />- if you passed your course and register for the next level<br />- if you participated at the placement test in Fall 2011<br /><br /><!-- / LIST OF COURSE PROPS --></td>&#13;

                                                                                                        This intermediate course is designed for students with basic knowledge of German (courses of B1.1 level or equivalent). You will learn how to understand simple newspaper texts as well as the main point of radio or TV programs.                 <input type="hidden" name="min_participantsno" value="6" /><input type="hidden" name="max_participantsno" value="42" /><!-- Reggroup,prioscheme,alloscheme,waitlist --><br /><br /><b>Partial Grades: </b><br />Attendance (25%, Mandatory)<br />Final Exam (25%)<br />Home Work (25%)<br />Midterm Exam (25%)&#13;
                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory. Students who miss more than 3 classes without a valid excuse will fail the course.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is designed as an advanced intermediate language course for students who have completed courses of B2.1 level or equivalent. <br />Course objectives are to further increase the student's proficiency in the four skills: speaking, listening, reading and writing. You will get able to understand extended speech and lectures, you will understand and discuss articles and reports concerning contemporary problems. You will write essays or reports on a wide range of subjects passing on information or giving reasons in support of or against a particular point of view. You will learn how to give a presentation in German.<br /><br />The language learning will be supported by the use of various media, which provides the learner with up-to-date contact with culture and the socio-behavioral patterns in Germany. <br /><br />Students attending this course can thereby reach language level B2 (according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages).<br /><br />For a detailed description of all language levels according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages).<br /><br />Further information on the weekly schedule of your section and the material that will be covered will be provided by the instructor.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;

                                <br /><b>Further Grading Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Attendance is mandatory. Students who miss more than 3 classes without a valid excuse will fail the course.<br /><b>Official Course Description</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        This course is designed for students with profound knowledge of German (courses of C1 level or equivalent). You can read and discuss longer texts and you can already use German flexibly and effectively for social, academic and professional purposes. Course objectives are to improve your listening skills by delivering German at fast native speed whether live or broadcast and teach you more idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms. The writing skills will be improved by writing summaries or reviews of academic, professional, or literary works. <br /><br />This course will prepare you for the TestDaF examination.<br /><br />Further information on the weekly schedule of your section and the material that will be covered will be provided by the instructor.<br /><br /><b>Additional Information</b>:<br />&#13;
                                                                                                        Courses with less than 6 participants will not take place.
